PETITION.TITLE: Isabella Plains Catholic Secondary School: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1. They are concerned that in the Tuggeranong Valley area of the ACT, no non-government schools have Year 11 and 12 places.
2. They want the new Catholic secondary school to be built at Isabella Plains to go to Year 12.

The petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensure that adequate resources are provided by the Government to allow Year 11 and 12 places to be provided at the Catholic Secondary School at Isabella Plains in accordance with the Government's commitment to a dual system of education and greater school retention to Year 12.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Identity Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Identity Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the introduction of a compulsory national identification system under the control of the Federal Government.

2. That we reject the identity card proposal because it will involve massive expenditure of taxpayers funds while being ineffective in combating the problems of tax evasion, illegal immigration and abuse of the social security system.
3. That we are deeply concerned at the invasion of each Australian's privacy and the loss of their freedom that would occur if the identity card was introduced.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate should: Reject the identity card or allow for a national referendum so the Australian people can decide themselves whether they want the costly, ineffective and intrusive un-Australian identity system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider the Federal Government's decision to have Telecom charge for the cost of `Directory Assistance' inquiries will greatly disadvantage, the sick, the elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the Government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for ``Directory Assistance'' inquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effective in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Dawson electorate respectfully shows that:
the Hawke Labour Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal, and that the card will not stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate will urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information, will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.

Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and

Epilepsy is a physical condition not a mental illness.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I sought leave to make this statement, frankly, because of the lack of interest by the Senate yesterday in the report which Senator Collins put down on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Honourable senators who were paying attention yesterday would have realised that another little bit of history was being made by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It must be some kind of record for Senator Collins and the Committee to have nursed along some 21 notices of motion for the past four weeks or so, to have obtained a catalogue of promised amendments by Ministers and, in the process, to have lost none of the legislation to disallowance at the end of the day. It is another demonstration of the power and authority of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the significance its work has in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: When the notices of motion were given on 22 October this year, I made a statement expressing my view that the Committee was possibly the most important committee we have in the Senate because of its apolitical watch-dog role. The process of subordinate law making, apparently by Ministers but in reality by departmental bureaucrats, can be assisted only by their paying close attention to the kinds of flaws and problems in the law which the Committee brings to light. The Committee's great strengths are its long-standing bipartisan tradition, its avoidance of criticism of the merits of delegated legislation, its lack of political motivation and its concentration on technical and legal issues of principle regarding personal rights and parliamentary propriety.

There are also, of course, the statutory disallowance powers of the Senate, which, to the credit of successive governments, are cast to allow for proper parliamentary supervision of subordinate law made under parliamentary authorisation. Also, this Senate has consistently backed the Committee with its own authority and that is a factor which has greatly strengthened the hand of the Committee in dealing with Ministers and officials who fail to see the need for unsatisfactory law-making to be called to account in the Parliament. I remind the Senate that none of those strengths arrived out of the blue. They were fought for by successive committees and committee chairmen over many years.

The vital bipartisanship of the Committee is no accident either. In the hard cases that sometimes arise, it is not easy for Government senators to resist the threat of criticism from their own Ministers or their Party because on the Committee they joined with Opposition senators to obtain an important amendment, to some regulation to protect personal rights or parliamentary scrutiny. Neither is it easy for Opposition senators to adhere rigidly to the Committee's rule of not making political capital out of the Committee's work. Yet for years these standards have been maintained by both sides of the Committee. I believe that the Committee enjoys higher standards of bipartisanship and non-political scrutiny than any comparable committee in the parliamentary world. I congratulate Senator Collins and the Committee on their works in the last month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 so as to promote the more efficient conduct of the operations of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation (Corporation) and its member banks. The Bill also defines more clearly the relationships between the Commonwealth banks and the Government, having regard to the Government's general policy in relation to statutory authorities, and introduces a dividend requirement for the Commonwealth Development Bank (Development Bank).

These measures were decided upon following a major review of the Commonwealth Banks Act by the Corporation and the Department of the Treasury. The review identified those areas of the Act which serve to inhibit the efficiency of operation of the Commonwealth banks and constrain their competitiveness and profit- ability. I note that major amendments were made to the Act in 1984 to strengthen the capital base of the Commonwealth banks and provide a more efficient organisational structure. These amendments complement those earlier initiatives and will place the Corporation banks in a position where they will be able to compete more effectively in the banking sector.

The main provisions of the Bill were foreshadowed in the Treasurer's press release of 27 October 1987. Among the significant amendments contained in the Bill are amendments which provide for the expansion of the functions and powers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (Commonwealth Bank) and the Commonwealth Savings Bank (Savings Bank).

The Bill expands the Charter of the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank to enable them to provide a wider range of insurance services where the board is satisfied this is necessary for them to be competitive with other banks. Under the present Act, they are precluded from providing insurance services except in respect of housing insurance for their own customers. The proposed changes will enable the Corporation banks to provide insurance products similar to those now available from other commercial banks.

The Bill will also expand the powers of the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank to include a wider range of banking and investment services. The range of powers listed reflects the activities that other banks are now undertaking following the deregulation of the financial system, including trusts, stockbroking, futures and commodities dealings. Under the present Act, the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank have been circumscribed in their capacity to extend the services they may offer.

The powers of the Development Bank have also been expanded to reflect the range of activities it is appropriate for the Development Bank to undertake. The overall effect of these changes will be to ensure that the Commonwealth banks will be on an equal footing with the private commercial banks in the range of services they can offer.

The review also focused on the role of the board and management of the banks and their accountability to the Government. Having regard to the Government's policies in relation to statutory authorities, the Bill introduces a requirement for the board to prepare and submit a corporate plan to the Treasurer. The plan, which will be confidential to the Government, will define the banks' corporate objectives and give an outline of the policies and strategies to be pursued in achieving them. In specifying objectives, the board will be required to include reference to financial objectives, including the level of profitability and the rate of return on resources.

The Bill also provides the board of the Corporation with a formal role in the determination of a dividend payment by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Savings Bank. Under the arrangements proposed, the board will recommend a dividend payment to the Commonwealth, having regard to the need to achieve a reasonable rate of return on capital and to maintain capital reserves to meet prudential requirements. The Treasurer will be able to accept or vary the recommendation up to the present maximum of 45 per cent of the profits of the banks.

In the 1987-88 Budget the Treasurer announced that a dividend requirement for the Commonwealth Development Bank is to be introduced. The Government believes that such a requirement is consistent with the Development Bank operating on a commercial basis. In respect of earnings in 1987-88, the Bill provides for an interim dividend of $6.9m to be paid in 1987-88 and a final dividend payment to be paid in 1988-89. Factors to be taken into account in determining the final dividend payment from 1987-88 profits and in subsequent years, will be similar to those outlined above for the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank.

The Bill will also give the Corporation greater flexibility in staff management through the repeal of those sections of the Act dealing with appointments, promotions, tenure of office and discipline of staff. These changes to the Act are consistent with the Government's recent initiatives in seeking to improve the efficiency of the public sector by reviewing work practices.

At the same time, however, the Bill includes a new provision to ensure that all appointments, promotions or transfers by the Corporation are made having regard to the application of the merit principle.

This will require the Corporation to make appointments, promotions or transfers in accordance with procedures that preclude patronage and favouritism and take into account the attributes of applicants to undertake the duties of a position. The Bill also makes transitional provisions to preserve any rights an officer may have when the amendments to conditions of service come into effect.

The Bill includes other minor legislative changes which will remove unnecessary administrative procedures and further improve the efficiency of operation and competitiveness of the Commonwealth banks. These amendments include the repeal of Part VI of the Act, which sets out arrangements under which the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank may make housing loans available. Such provisions are no longer necessary as both banks have the requisite powers to make housing loans under other sections of the Act. The repeal of this part will also serve to enhance the flexibility available to the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank in developing innovative packages to assist home buyers and will ensure that the Commonwealth banks are on an equal footing with the other banks in the range of home lending facilities they can offer.

The Bill also repeals that section of the present Act which requires oversight by the Treasurer of the Development Bank's borrowing activities. Now that the Development Bank is operating on a fully commercial basis this requirement is no longer appropriate.

In terms of the financial impact of this Bill, the introduction of a dividend requirement for the Development Bank will result in payment of $6.9m to the Commonwealth in the 1987-88 financial year and the Commonwealth should benefit from dividend payments from the Development Bank in future years. Improvements in the competitiveness of the Commonwealth banks arising from this package of amendments should enhance profitability and give rise to increased dividend payments in future years. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. The amendments are set out in the Schedule to this Bill.

The Murray-Darling Basin comprises about one-seventh of Australia. It produces about one-third of Australia's total output from natural resource-based industries. It supports 25 per cent of the nation's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and cropland, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. Production derived is valued at some $10 billion annually. It is Australia's agricultural heartland.

We have been historically successful in our approach to harvesting the waters of the Basin to ensure reliable supplies for irrigation, urban and industrial use. This success, however, has to be measured against the costs of deteriorating water and land quality and diminished environmental amenity.

Inadequate attention to the need for an environmentally and economically integrated approach to natural resource management in the Basin has, however, in some instances already set in train resource degradation processes that threaten resource viability.

Indeed, it is hard to escape the conclusion that in many ways, past land, water and environmental management practices have been largely exploitive and not conducive to sustainable use of the resources of the Basin.
Historically, debate has focused on the security and use of the priceless waters of the River Murray, a non insignificant factor in accelerating the advent of Federation.

The first River Murray Waters Agreement, to resolve developing conflicts in the use of River Murray waters, was signed in 1914, legislation came into effect in 1915 and the River Murray Commission was established in 1917.

As a result of the first major review of the Agreement in 1983, the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission were extended to include water quality matters but an holistic approach to Basin resource management remained elusive Not that this should be surprising to anyone.

Management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Basin involves three State Governments (four if you include Queensland) and the Commonwealth, as well as a multiplicity of local government and regional agencies. It requires the reconciliation of the disparate interests and aspirations of a diverse population of over two million people within boundaries encompassing in excess of one million square kilometres.
This reconciliation, while necessarily predicated on sound technical analyses, must inevitably involve hard political and economic choices between competing objectives and measures.

The breakthrough came in November 1985 when Ministers of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, with responsibility for natural resources, met to discuss specifically strategies to improve natural resource management in the Basin.
In a genuinely historic initiative, the four governments decided to shelve parochial interests and adopt a strong, co-operative approach to better management of the Basin.

The most immediately visible outcome of the meeting was the agreement to establish a Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council on an ongoing basis. Ministers also initiated a wide-ranging work program to develop institutional and technical options for improved Basin management.

Council met in August 1986 and in March 1987. In the light of its deliberations and the substantial body of advice provided by its advisory committee, all four Governments have now agreed to substantially revise the institutional arrangements for managing the Basin. The Bill currently before the Senate complements similar legislation before the Parliaments of the other three signatories and aims to have in place by 1 January 1988, an institutional framework at inter-governmental level that will facilitate and support State-based initiatives.
The amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement will give a clear legislative base to the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council.

The Council will provide a focus for consideration of planning and management issues for the sustainable use of the natural resources of the Basin. It will be responsible for the development of policies and strategies for their efficient, equitable and co-ordinated management.

Composed of those Ministers representing the portfolios of water, land and environment from the four governments, the Council will be in a position to make informed political judgements and balanced trade-off decisions.

It will be able to take a holistic, overview stance on management issues. It is this that distinguishes the current initiative from past endeavours which have been State-based or, in the case of the River Murray Waters Agreement, confined to the regulation of a particular resource or aspects of it.

The amendments before the Senate also propose the establishment of a new Murray-Darling Basin Commission to replace the River Murray Commission. This new Commission will assume the River Murray Commission's regulatory responsibilities under the River Murray Waters Agreement, and will also have a broader advisory responsibility to the Ministerial Council on land, environment and water matters not covered in the Agreement.
Another important element in the proposed legislation is the provision for a direct line of communication between Council and the Basin community.

From the very outset, Ministers have been mindful of the crucial role that the community will play in the development of improved management practices in the Basin. Accordingly, the proposed legislation includes express provision for a Community Advisory Committee to provide a focus for community input.

The formation of a community forum will allow the great variety of local interests the opportunity for consultation on the management of the Basin's natural resources. Such a body will perform the vital role of eliciting and synthesising-so far as is possible-the diversity of community views on particular management issues, and will provide an avenue for two way communication between the Council and the people of the Basin.

Consultation must, of course, involve more than drawing community concerns to Council's attention. Consultation must also carry responsibilities, and private aspirations may well need to be modified in the light of the larger public benefit.
It will be essential to the success of the Basin initiative that the community accept both the opportunities and the responsibilities of involvement provided for under this legislation.
The Government is confident that the legislation currently before the Senate will provide an institutional framework commensurate with the task to be done.
Ultimate success will depend upon a close, responsible and responsive partnership between all the Governments involved and between Governments and the people of the Basin.
The Council will need to move with cautious speed. Success will not be achieved easily or overnight, and a long term commitment is required.

But the Basin community and the nation will benefit from our efforts to secure the long-term integrity of the natural resources of the Basin. That is a goal very much worth striving for. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration: An itemised costing and ongoing review until project completion of the proposed satellite monitoring and communications station at Geraldton, and the reasons for the increase in estimated costs from around $25 million to around $300 million.

In March this year, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced in a White Paper that the Government plans to enhance Australia's independent intelligence capabilities by establishing a large satellite communications station in Western Australia. The station, the White Paper said, will contribute to Australia's security in our area of strategic interest, and will be totally Australian-owned and staffed and operated by the Defence Signals Directorate. Subsequent Press articles in the Age and the Australian Financial Review estimated the cost to be from $20m to $25m, with between 300 and 400 staff working there. Later we were told that the station would be near Geraldton. A site has obviously been chosen, as the Government has informed a local farming family, the Martins, that 400 hectares of their 1,000-hectare farm are being taken over.

The Government, however, refuses to give any official estimate of the cost of the Geraldton facility, which I find strange, given that in October 1978, in answer to Question No. 1253, cost figures were given for North West Cape, Pine Gap and Nurrungar. I find it even stranger, in light of the Defence Minister's Press statement of 18 February 1986, that the Government was going to provide as much information as possible about the joint Australian-US facilities. Yet, we now have a situation where a Labor government is being more secretive than its Liberal predecessor and going back on its earlier statement about being more open. If Mr Beazley was not referring to Australian facilities, but only to the joint facilities, it is very worrying, although perhaps not surprising when we consider the fact that Australian citizens can find out more about what is going on in this country under the United States Freedom of Information Act than under our own Freedom of Information Act. Perhaps it is due to the fact that the Government realised that it could not hide the facts and figures about the so-called joint facilities, but it is certainly attempting to hide the facts about this Australian facility.

It is also somewhat contradictory to hear Senator Robert Ray say that it is not the practice of the Government to release details of the specific costs of such facilities when we have the earlier figures for the three joint facilities alongside the Defence Minister's pledge of providing more information on these bases. What makes this more serious is that, according to two officers of the Department of Administrative Services who visited the Martins' farm on 23 October, Messrs Colin Eckert and Ross Temple, the value of the whole project was of the order of $300m, a figure far removed from the estimates given in March in the Age and the Financial Review, which I assume those papers got from some fairly reliable sources. In answer to my question on the subject on 20 November, Senator Ray said that the public servants concerned were not authorised to give out any information about the total projected cost of the new planned facility, adding that the land was not being compulsorily seized either. On whose behalf were Eckert and Temple speaking? What exactly is their official capacity?

The Defence Minister's Press release 137-87 indicated that $413m was being spent on new major facilities. If housing is subtracted from this total, that leaves $304.458m. This equates to the figure of $304.298m for proposed new works under division 245.1.02 of the Budget Papers-Department of Defence, New Works contracted by the Department of Administrative Services-which would include the Geraldton communications station. From this, we can subtract other major works named by the Minister, namely, Mulwala for explosives, Darwin for naval support and East Sale for the Royal Australian Air Force, totalling $66m. That leaves $238.3m unaccounted for, which I assume to be the maximum cost for the Geraldton facility.

Not only am I concerned that the Government is being misleading about the costs of this project, but also I am puzzled as to why we have to build such a large facility to enhance Australia's security. If the Geraldton station gives us the capability to monitor satellites between 50 degrees east and 180 degrees east or 60 degrees east and west of Geraldton, all the satellites concerned-and there are 121 of them-belong to countries with which we are reason- ably friendly, apart from the Soviet Union. The other countries concerned are the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, India, China, Indonesia, Japan and Papua New Guinea and, of course, there are our own satellites.

Two of these countries are involved with Australia in the 1947 UK-USA intelligence sharing agreement, and the Defence Minister has already hinted, in March this year, that the United States would share intelligence from the facility. Given that the computers for the Geraldton facility are probably from the United States, this is hardly surprising. Neither will the importing of massive amounts of high-tech equipment help our trade deficit and balance of payments. Then there are countries whose communications could be of intelligence interest to Australia and our allies-namely, France and Italy, who are both members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, India, Indonesia, Japan, Papua New Guinea and obviously the Soviet Union. On the other hand, we are on close terms with all those countries bar the Soviet Union, and I do not think it is conducive to good neighbourly relations openly to tap into their satellite communications and then share that information with the members of the exclusive Anglo-Saxon club involved in the 1947 agreement.

I am also curious to know whether one-third of the earth's surface-that is 50 degrees east to 180 degrees east or the international date line-constitutes Australia's area of strategic interest. According to the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, Australia's area of strategic interest covered 10 to 20 per cent of the earth's surface. So it seems strange that our intelligence capabilities have to cover so much more of the globe. Also, I would like to ask how the Government intends to acquire the Martin family's land if the family does not want to sell it. Senator Ray said that the Government is not going to compulsorily purchase the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seize.

—Seize, acquire or buy. If the Martin family does not want to sell it, how will the Government actually ensure that a satisfactory arrangement is entered into? Mrs Martin said that the Department of Administrative Services has offered her family $150,000 for the 400-hectare section of the farm designated for the base, although the family's valuer has said that it is worth at least $300,000. As Mrs Martin said, `How do you put a value on something you do not want to sell?'. Therefore, how will the Government acquire the chosen land? At first locals were told that 24 people would be travelling from Geraldton to run the facility. Now they are being told that there will be 200 cars a day along a bitumen road. Obviously, the Government's plans have changed dramatically since the initial announcements in March. Everything about the facility seems to have escalated almost vertically since then.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government should be honest and tell us exactly what it is planning near Geraldton and how much it will cost the taxpayer. What is the Government hiding? It should not pretend that this project is all top secret, when details have been made available to Australian taxpayers in the past on the costings of the so-called joint intelligence facilities. This project is meant to be totally Australian except, of course, for the end use to which the gathered information will be put. The Pentagon planners must be laughing. This time a foolish Australian government is not only providing additional information to the United States, but is doing so at no cost whatsoever to the United States. We gather and provide the information to the United States to suit its purposes, and we pay. What suckers we are. Therefore, for an Australian government to present this project as totally Australian is dishonest.

For any Australian government also to try to hide from the taxpayers what millions of Australian dollars, to the tune of roughly $300m, will be spent on is an outrageous abrogation of the notion of government accountability. We have a right to know what the Government is doing on our behalf. We demand to know the costings of this facility. They are being hidden from us, I suspect, because the Government has plans to build something much larger and with much more significant spying implications than it dares to admit. That is not good enough. Not only the people of Geraldton, but all Australians have a right to know what is going on. In the interests of open government and taxpayers' right to information, referral of this project until its completion to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is essential. I commend this motion to all honourable senators.

When our Government came into office in 1983 we had unprecedented unemployment-record high levels of unemployment in virtually every section of the work force. Under those absolutely traumatic circumstances, a program such as the CEP was, in our view, justified. We had to move dramatically to create very quickly a whole range of short term employment opportunities for people who had been on the unemployment scrap-heap for a very long time. We never intended that the CEP would last forever. We always regarded it as a short term measure which we would put into place to give the long term unemployed some experience of employment while we were attending to the major problems of the economy.

As Senator Michael Baume will be very well aware, employment has grown substantially during the several Hawke administrations to a point where we judged that programs such as the CEP had served their purpose and we were now in a position to move on to a different emphasis, and that was the formal training of unemployed persons to fill gaps existing in the labour market. The reason for our decision to wind down the CEP, unfortunately for Senator Baume but I think fortunately for the community, had nothing to do with Senator Baume's very biased and unfair criticisms of particular grants that went to organisations which he happens not to like. That is not to say that there are not labour market problems or that we still do not have, in many respects, an underskilled work force. But the overwhelming crisis of unemployment which we faced when we came into office, which justified a program such as the CEP, has been modified to the stage where we can look now at more formal training opportunities through technical and further education colleges and the like. Our emphasis is on training rather than on job creation. We believe that our discussions with employers in the public and private sectors are fruitful enough for us to be able to identify school shortages and to ensure that unemployed people are directed to undertake training in appropriate areas-that is, areas which will have a high chance of providing them with jobs after they complete their training.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the attention of the Committee to the continual doctor bashing being undertaken at the moment by one of the Government's committees. It is unfair, unreasonable and deliberately misleading. I believe that it is being assisted, to some extent, by Ministers, and that borders on being disgraceful when, in so many instances, the Government claims to be co-operating with the medical profession in establishing the manner in which the Australian public is provided with a health service.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the price watch operation set up by the Government under Mr Gear, a member of the House of Representatives, has in recent times quite savagely attacked doctors and their fees. I think people who read the Bulletin would at least get a reasonable view of the position of the general practitioner, which is far from healthy in financial terms and which has been steadily going down in recent years as the Government has set about dismantling Medicare. The latest moves, which I just mentioned to the Minister, involve a reduction in the amount to be paid for medical services when the patient is in hospital from 85 per cent to 75 per cent. That further increases the burden on individual Australians when they have medical attention. Even if the doctors are paid the Medicare fees established by the Government, in many cases these fees are far below the sort of fees which are needed to make the service viable.

What we have here is a situation in which the Government is saying not only that the scheduled fee is the right and proper fee and charging anything above that is improper, but also that it will not even pay that fee to the doctor, and it will encourage doctors to bulk bill so that they do not get that fee. Something like 50 per cent of medical fees paid under Medicare, as I noted from the Health Insurance Commission's annual report, are bulk billed. In other words, doctors are not even getting the schedule fee in those instances. It strikes me as extraordinary that this fairly vicious campaign against the medical profession, particularly against the hard-pressed general practitioners, should proceed.

This is galling for doctors, and I think for all Australians who are concerned about getting a decent health service. Unless there is an adequate reward system for the medical profession, the incentive for people to devote so many years of their life to becoming experts in this area may well be diminished. I am not saying that financial considerations are the only things that prompt people to become doctors-they are not. But when there are so many other highly-rewarded alternative opportunities for people with the intellectual skills required to get into medical degree courses-for example, in computers and so on-it seems ludicrous that the Government should be so unfair and, I believe, mendacious in its approach to the medical profession.

It is nonsensical to pretend that there is one fee for a particular service which must be charged by all doctors. Everyone recognises that when we go, for example, to a supermarket there are some products we can buy that are cheaper than others, probably because they do not have the same quality. In the medical profession there are some doctors who happen to be better than others at doing particular things. Of course, that is especially so at the level of specialist or consultant services. There are some doctors who, quite properly, get a very high reputation. There are some members of the Senate whom one would not even bother raising an issue with or going to see if one were a constituent because one knows that they are sufficiently incompetent, particularly if sitting on the other side of the chamber, not to be effective.

In other words, this Government is adopting the lowest common denominator in regard to health. It is saying that anyone who charges above the schedule fee somehow is being improper. That is what Mr Gear and his Government supported committee are saying. They are saying that we are being overcharged if we are charged more than the schedule fee. I do not hear similar complaints in regard to undercharging if we are bulk billed. That logic, apparently, escapes the Minister and her cronies. The Government has shown by its own assertions and its own behaviour that the schedule fee is, in fact, not the specific fee which must be charged in all instances. The Government's own actions encourage doctors to charge less. Nor does the Government pretend that it should be the maximum fee, except, of course, when it is playing politics against the doctors.

Here we have a situation in which some doctors, quite properly, because of their additional skills, are entitled to charge more, just as the patient is entitled to ask, if he wants to, what fee the doctor is going to charge for a service and to go to a doctor who may well be prepared to offer the service for less. That is what the free market is all about. It is something that the Government is yet to understand, although it keeps talking about its support for free market economics.

The other health insurance question that I wish to raise relates to the attempts by Mr Gear and the price watch committee which the Government has set up to say that health insurance should operate on the same commercial basis as general insurance. Mr Gear asked why, if one were insured through Medicare, one should have to pay more than the schedule fee if one went to a particular doctor. Of course, the whole point is that, if one insures one's house through an insurance company, one pays a premium which allows for the full replacement cost of that house. This is not what Medicare does. In the first place Medicare specifically prohibits the full payment and, secondly, Medicare insurance goes about one-third of the way towards paying for the provision of Medicare. So this Government has no reasonable capacity for pretending that health insurance is like house insurance. If the Government freed up the market and allowed patients to take out full health cover so that they did not have to pay anything-this Government specifically prohibits that-there is no doubt that health insurance premiums for that full health cover would rise, but they would rise to a level which would enable people to insure fully for their health care, just as people are allowed in the free market to insure fully for the replacement of their houses.

I notice that Mr Gear, as part of the continu-ing campaign of knocking doctors, quoted from a table produced by the Health Insurance Commission showing the extent of observance of the Medicare fee schedule in the June quarter of 1987. He claims, for example, that it shows that ACT medical practitioners in general charge far more than their State counterparts. He says that the difference between the States is somehow significant. If Mr Gear and the Government referred to a table on page 95 of the annual report of the Health Insurance Commission, they would see some figures which explain why this might be the case. Contrary to the table which Mr Gear cites in saying that the reason New South Wales general practitioners charge less than others is that there is an over-supply of them-in other words, that somehow doctors in the Australian Capital Territory are behaving improperly as against doctors in New South Wales-it can be seen from the table to which I refer that in New South Wales the average value of benefit processed per enrolled person is $205.10, whereas in the Australian Capital Territory it is only $145.52. In other words, the cost to the Health Insurance Commission of what is put forward here as some kind of overcharging is, in fact, demonstrated to be less on average in the Australian Capital Territory than in New South Wales. There may be some special reasons for this, such as people going to Sydney for specialist treatment and so on.

I draw to the attention of the Government the fact that it is nonsense to put out figures showing how many people observe the Medicare fee schedule without acknowledging such things as how many doctors bulk bill and the average value of the benefit processed. In New South Wales, as I said, it was $205.10; in Victoria, only $159.68; in South Australia, $170.98; and, in Western Australia, $146.53. Perhaps we could hear some explanation from the Minister for those extraordinary variations between the States in the level of benefit processed for each person enrolled in Medicare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation for the Department of Community Services and Health stands apart from other appropriations in that it bites largely into the Government's Budget. It is a huge sum of money. Of course, health matters strike the household of every Australian. The Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) would recall that on 24 September I asked a question without notice to which she gave a response, which I appreciated. The question concerned the position in which general practitioners (GPs) find themselves in in building a practice based essentially on preventive medicine philosophy rather than curative medicine philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: I cited the case of a doctor known to me in my local area, a Dr Mark Donohoe, who has been attempting to pursue this line of practice for some four years and has done so with extraordinary success in that he now has a practice of 4,000, whereas the national norm is, I believe, in the vicinity of 1,500 to 1,700. Some of the people who consult Dr Donohoe found that in a random pattern their claims were being refused, particularly for pathology. That leads us to the controversial area of screening, overcharging and so on. It raises the whole position in which general practitioners find themselves. I emphasise that Dr Donohoe is a general practitioner and is not in the area of what might broadly be described as alternative medicine. He practices as a general practitioner and people approach him as such only to find, to their surprise, that, although for some time they may have had their claims reimbursed, all of a sudden that stops and without explanation their claims for pathology charges are knocked back.

This matter raises two significant areas of principle and, therefore, the whole question of how these costings in any way can be accurate unless these questions of principle are first answered. One principle concerns the overall attitude to a practitioner who is pursuing essentially a philosophy of preventive medicine and therefore believes professionally that certain charges are justified, only to find that he is interfacing with a bureaucracy that does not accept that strategy. So there is a problem for the practitioner. But a more important point of principle is that the people who present themselves to the general practitioners in good faith, and on the assumption that Medicare undertakes to provide all Australians with free medical services as a result of their having paid the one per cent levy, believe they are entitled to free medical services. But when they present themselves in good faith to a professional who has `General Practitioner' on his plate they find that their good faith does not carry through into the system. For some time they get their reimbursements then, all of a sudden, they do not.

That denial is tied up with another difficult area-a squabble between a general practitioner who was pursuing a particular philosophy and the system and who finds himself in difficult circumstances. One of the 200 patients, of Dr Donohoe's 4,000 patients, who formed a patients action committee to defend him in his struggles in this regard against the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) decided to pursue the issue with the New South Wales Ombudsman. I have no doubt that the Ombudsman carried the matter to as satisfactory a conclusion as was possible. But it did not satisfy the patient. It did not change the situation in the slightest. However, the Ombudsman sent to the patient an eight-page computer printout of that person's medical history. It was a printout from the HIC. It accidentally came into the hands of this patient because he had made inquiries through the channels of the Ombudsman. This matter gives rise to the question: Is there sitting in a file somewhere a dossier on every Australian?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there is.

—Senator Puplick says there is. We are harking back to a debate some weeks ago in relation to the HIC. That is precisely where we are; back in the arena of the HIC, of databases and of people discovering accidentally that such records exist-in this case, eight pages of them. We are back in the arena of whether the HIC is sufficiently credible in terms of its security--
—And has given them to the police on occasions.

—Those records have been provided, on occasions, to the police and have been published on the front pages of newspapers, through leaks from the HIC. I am posing three questions. Two are questions of principle and one is a question of specific cost. The first question is: Are the bureaucracy, the Department and the Government, in terms of claims, coming to grips with the whole philosophical interface between preventive versus curative medicine? Secondly, does the Department acknowledge that there is a clear breach of the principle of assured and guaranteed free health service provisions when people present in good faith to a GP only to have their claims denied because that GP is unacceptable to the system? We could probe the whole criteria of acceptability and unacceptability, but that is a can of worms we really do not want to open. The third question is: Do such dossiers exist on every registered claimant under Medicare? If so, what is the cost of compiling such dossiers, what is the accessibility, and to whom does that accessibility extend in relation to medical histories?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to answer questions insofar as questions were posed but really the honourable senator was taking the opportunity to make some general observations.
—There were three specific questions right at the end.

—There were three questions but I am not quite sure how specific they were. The honourable senator asked, in terms similar to these, whether the Government supports the philosophy of preventive care. We certainly do. Many of the activities of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health are targeted towards preventive activities. That does not mean, of course, that every proposal put up by every doctor has to attract a payment under the Medicare schedule. The Government has taken the view, as the result of various advice, that multiphasic health screening is not as effective a form of preventive care as doctors ordering specific diagnostic tests. That is a decision the Government is entitled to make. No doubt there is some debate around that. The removal of this item from the schedule will not have any significant effect on the investigation of patients' conditions using conventional facilities. In other words, the conventional facilities are adequate. Maybe doctors can make some use of these other facilities but our advice has led us to the view that they are not justified under the Medicare benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether people are being denied access to services, clearly they are not. Doctors can provide the services if they wish. However, if the Government judges those services as not appropriate for the Medicare schedule, they do not attract benefits. It is important to note the difference between access to a service and access to a benefit. Finally, the whole question of the Health Insurance Commission's security, dossiers and so forth, redolent of the debate on the Australia Card about which we heard so much in this place, has been raised again by the honourable senator. I simply point out, without going to all the issues which have been very extensively debated here and could be on another occasion, that the Government is paying out money on behalf of the taxpayers of Australia to people who have undergone certain medical procedures. It is therefore entitled, and has a responsibility, to ensure that proper records are kept for those payments and there is proper accountability. If, in the honourable senator's mind, that constitutes a dossier, so be it. But it would be impossible to run a universal health insurance system without having lists of the schedules under which claims were made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My last question was specific to the cost of keeping such records. I would be happy for the Minister to take that on notice. It is an unreasonable question without notice. I am really asking what portion of that vast sum of money spent on public health goes into the processing of records that most people do not even know exist and whose security we have doubts about. I would like to respond to some of the Minister's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not accept that the system at large is sufficiently accommodating claims emanating from a medical practice built upon the philosophy of preventive medicine, because eventually those claims bump up against a formula, a list, a schedule that is built out of the conventional model. So there is a clash between the two approaches. For instance, I return to the practice of Dr Mark Donohoe. When he started his practice four years ago he philosophically said that he was going to prescribe as few drugs as possible. Most people would nod their heads and say that that would be a very responsible point from which to proceed. From that starting point he proceeded to practice his medicine. In order for him to abide by his philosophical approach of prescribing as few drugs as possible he considered that he had to use other services, one of which is pathology; but he uses virtually no pharmacology and little radiology.

Claims for his services heap in the area associated with pathology but they trough in the areas associated with other dimensions of expense. The computer throws him up as being abnormal in the way in which he practices his medicine. Because he is abnormal in comparison with a conventional model he is cited for close examination and he immediately moves into a process of heavy dialogue and initially discussion and finally strong interaction, possibly legal interaction, with the system which he is trying to accommodate. So I do not accept that the system is acknowledging the legitimacy of alternative philosophies, philosophies which are espoused in our medical schools.

My son is a doctor. He graduated from the University of Newcastle, which has deliberately created different approaches to the training of its doctors. When those doctors move out of the medical schools where they have been taught to espouse philosophies of preventive medicine into general practice and attempt to put that approach into practice they come up against a system which, for probably good bureaucratic reasons, is lagging behind in accommodating their requirements. So two people suffer: the practitioner and the patient. I do not accept the fact that people are being denied repayment. People who attend this doctor's surgery attend there in good faith. They get some of their pathology claims repaid and they do not get some of the others repaid. They are being denied. They are being denied in one week--

TALK.START.PARA: —Payment, not service.

—I never claimed they were being denied service. Many of them could turn their backs on that practice if they wished to but they are satisfied by it in all sorts of other ways which the system, I understand, cannot accommodate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions concern the Department of Community Services and Health and Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88. SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the major sums of money paid to the Medical Research Endowment Fund and allocated by way of other research grants that are dealt with on page 31 of an appendix to Appropriation Bill (No. 1). The amount of money allocated this year for medical research is $64,365,000. That amount of money is certainly not adequate for the many persons who are undertaking beneficial research. There is also a problem regarding the types of priorities that are given by the National Health and Medical Research Council in its recommendations to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) for grants. I refer to the area of early human life. The amounts of money being provided to grantees run into millions of dollars. Most of those grants are not used for the purpose of protecting life at that stage; they are for the purpose of devising situations in which life can be utilised by others at that stage. I use the word `utilised' very seriously because I believe that most doctors who adhere to the hippocratic oath consider that their job is to preserve life.

Let me turn to a very substantial grant which was made on application by Professor Peter Singer, Dr Helga Kuhse and a Ms Gaze. The sum of $274,029 over three years has been allocated from taxpayers' funds for a project which is entitled `bioethical issues in the use of human foetal tissue, embryos and gamuts'. In this year the proposal, as I understand it, was for a grant of $91,343-not an insubstantial amount when one takes account of those researchers whose applications have been approved, but for whom money is not available for beneficial research.

What is this proposed research all about and who is to conduct it? There has been a bit of toing and froing about this matter. We were told last year that the research was to be undertaken by Professor Swan. He was to be the chief investigator. It now turns out that Professor Swan is certainly not the chief investigator of the project; Professor Peter Singer is the chief investigator of the project. Although Professor Swan is still the Chairman of the Centre for Human Bioethics the research is being conducted by Professor Singer, Dr Kuhse and Ms Gaze. They are at the Centre for Human Bioethics; nevertheless, Professor Swan is not the chief investigator. I wonder why Professor Swan was included in the response previously. Was it because the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council was concerned that to mention the names of Professor Singer and Dr Kuhse would raise very grave concern and questions amongst people who might consider the application?

I will detail to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, Senator Ryan, the view of Professor Singer and Dr Kuhse. Their view involves, essentially, extreme utilitarianism. Their view is that the human embryo and the foetus have no intrinsic rights. I will detail to the Minister what Professor Singer said in his submission to the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation. It is very important that this be understood. At page 489 of the transcript, he said:

Once an embryo may be capable of feeling pain, I believe that we need very strict controls over the experimentation which can be done with it. At this point, the embryo ranks, morally, with other creatures who are conscious but not self-conscious. Many non-human animals come into this category, and in my view they have often been unjustifiably made to suffer in scientific research. We should have stringent controls over research to ensure that this cannot happen to embryos, just as we should have stringent controls to ensure that it cannot happen to animals.
That is, after sentience. He continued:

The capacity to feel pain is enough to entitle a being to moral consideration. There are, however, different forms moral consideration can take. A right not to have pain inflicted upon one unnecessarily is not the same as a right to life. Finally, then, when does the developing person acquire a right to life? I would argue, following Michael Tooley, who has discussed this matter very thoroughly in his recent book Abortion and Infanticide that there must be something more: a sense of self, an awareness of the continuity of one's existence over time, a knowledge that one has a past and may have a future, and the capacity to have desires about that future. I think we can be confident that no embryo or foetus has these capacities. It is of course true that in this respect too birth does not mark a morally crucial dividing line, for the newborn infant equally lacks this kind of self-awareness. But this raises another topic, which I cannot go into now.

But it is gone into in a book entitled Should the Baby Live? by Helga Kuhse and Peter Singer. In that book they advocate, quite bluntly, euthanasia and infanticide-the killing of newborn babies. This is the group to which the Government has given $274,000 to study what research is appropriate for early human life. Let me quote from pages 196 and 197, the summation of Should the Baby Live?, by Helga Kuhse and Peter Singer, the deputy chief investigator and the chief investigator to whom all this money has been given. The book, in talking about legislation to enable infanticide to occur, states:
The change in the law would do no more than allow parents to make, shortly after birth, the decision that they are now legally entitled to make before birth-
those are their words; of course, it is incorrect-

to end a life which has started out with difficulties so great that it is best that it not be prolonged. Indeed, because of what we have said about adoption or other care when the infant's life can be a satisfying one, the parents would continue to have less right to end the life after birth than they now have before birth, in countries where abortion is freely available.

In one respect we do go further than the proposed Limitation of Treatment Bill. For the reasons already given, we would allow active as well as passive euthanasia to be carried out during the period before acceptance of the child into the community.

The Minister must answer why the Government-I admit on the recommendation of the National Health and Medical Research Council, and I will refer to it in a minute-has given $274,029 of taxpayers' money, over a quarter of a million dollars, to these people. What are they to do? According to their application they will:
(i) Continue to monitor the development of techniques for the use . . . of human foetal tissue . . . human gametes and embryos for scientific and clinical purposes; and
(ii) Assess the impact on researchers and clinicians of existing and proposed restrictions on these experiments-
note the words `Assess the impact on researchers and clinicians of existing and proposed restrictions on these experiments'-
and on the development and use of such techniques-
not the effect they are going to have on the human embryo, except as follows:
(iii) Assemble information relevant to the stage at which the foetus may become capable of experiencing pain.

Thus, the assumption is made that, prior to the capacity of the foetus to experience pain or, as presumed by Professor Singer, its awareness of its past and its future, everything is okay. That is what the group said on the scientific aspects. On the ethical aspects, it had this to say:
We shall carry out research into the ethical and social aspects of the above-mentioned techniques, paying particular attention to:

(iv) The use of ethics committees as a means of resolving ethical problems; their constitution, procedures, and modes of reasoning. We shall consider such committees at all levels, both within Australia and overseas, including bodies set up by national or state governments and research ethics committees at particular institutions;
(v) Procedures for obtaining appropriate consent for the use of embryonic and foetal tissue; and
(vi) The ethical issues raised by the possibility of inflicting pain on previable foetus.

Can the Minister see the assumptions? They are assuming that their extreme utilitarian philosophy is the base line. We are talking about a very substantial amount of money being paid out to this group of people, much to the chagrin, might I add, of a large number of reputable medical scientists who are being denied their fair share of public funds for beneficial research. I refer now to what is contained under the heading `Legal'. Here comes the trap; this is what it is all about. The application states:
(vii) To research existing law which may affect scientific research and researchers in this field, including legislation passed to regulate the areas such as-
reference is made to the Victorian legislation-
and to make suggestions for reform.
Does the Committee see what that says? It says:
To research existing law which may affect scientific research and researchers in this field, including legislation . . .
The application goes on:

(viii) To examine proposals for, and alternative available models of, schemes of regulation or prohibition of research into foetal tissue or in vitro human gametes or embryos, in Australia and overseas, that is, by institutional ethics committees, peer review, a licensing and monitoring body, or legislation with criminal sanctions.

(ix) To review the appropriateness and effectiveness of the regulatory models identified to achieve the aims for which they are proposed, including making recommendations which would identify the desired model or models.

I want to know from the Minister why these people have been given this enormous grant. Were they even an appropriate group to be given the grant, how can it be considered that three years is required for the undertaking of putting those things together? Is it not appropriate for the Minister to respond to these questions during the Committee's examination of these estimates?
