SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come very shortly to the question of the Medical Research Ethics Committee (MREC) and its expert advice in terms of the answers that I have been given in respect of the working party on the establishment of registers for genetic disorders and how it is terribly important for the Government that it know where the MREC is taking it. Before I do that, so that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) is again perfectly well aware of the attitudes of the chief investigator of this project, in respect of which over a quarter of a million dollars of taxpayers' money has been given, I would like to indicate where he would draw the line as to questions of rights. I refer to evidence given by Professor Singer and questioning that was directed to him when he was giving evidence to the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985. A great deal was said on pages 496 to 499 of the transcript. But in deference to honourable senators, I will not read all of the evidence. Professor Singer said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe any embryos ever have a right to live as embryos.
The Chairman, Senator Michael Tate, commented:
The same applies to the young child in your paper, as I understand it.
Professor Singer said:

If we move away from the question of the wrongness of inflicting pain which is a separate issue, in my view a right to life, specifically, is something that only develops as a being develops a capacity to understand itself as existing over time and therefore the capacity to have any kinds of wants or desires about its life. In other words, it is only at the point that it matters to the being whether it goes on living; that it can understand that notion of whether or not it goes on living.
The Chairman asked:
A mentally defective person who is not able to reach a certain stage of awareness, self-reflection and appreciation of his or her intrinsic worth would not have a right to life?

Professor Singer-This is a very severe level of mental retardation which we are talking about. It is obviously not that possessed by Down's syndrome children, for example, because they are clearly capable of that.
CHAIRMAN-You can assume that I am asking a question about a person who is unable to reach the level of self-awareness that you posit, as creating intrinsic worth between you and me.
Professor Singer-Such a being, in my view, has no intrinsic right to life.

I wonder whether the Government realised what its so-called expert body, the Medical Research Ethics Committee-which supported the Singer application to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), which in turn failed to examine it adequately-was getting into, particularly in view of the fact that this money is being used to attack a legislative foundation for the protection of the rights of individuals in our society. What is happening in this case is that money is being given to this group so it can attack our responsibility in Parliament to preserve those individual rights. The National Health and Medical Research Council recommended to the Medical Research Ethics Committee that assessments be done. In the Committee I asked whether that grant was made to Professor Swan and on what basis.

I went on to ask whether any MREC members could have suggested or inspired the application from Swan and his colleagues. The interesting answer that came back from the Department did not include the words `and his colleagues'. I had it on reliable authority that Singer and Kuhse had been asked by the MREC to develop this application. I said `Swan and his colleagues'. When the note came back from the Department it said:
Senator Harradine asked if any MREC or MREC Members could have suggested/inspired the application from Swan?
The answer was:
All persons who were members of the MREC in 1984, and who are contactable at present, has been asked the question. All have denied any involvement with Professor Swan regarding this matter.

That is not what I asked. I turn to the MREC and the question concerning registers of genetic disorders or, as they say, inherited disorders. In the Estimates Committee I asked whether a committee of inquiry had been established to consider the question of registers of genetic disorders. When I asked that question in the Estimates Committee, an answer from the departmental officer was:
As a member of the National Health and Medical Research Council, I am at this stage not aware of this.

I do not know what happens at these National Health and Medical Research Council meetings-whether they rubber stamp everything that comes up from the MREC. The answer the Committee has now been given in writing reads:

There has been no Committee of inquiry and there have been no investigations around Australia. The Department is informed that the NHMRC at its meeting in November 1986 requested its Medical Research Ethics Committee . . . to give priority for consideration of this topic, as it was aware of the ethical problems associated with the keeping of registers and family records of patients with genetically determined diseases. The Council agreed-
after having said that there was no committee, listen to this-
to a working party of MREC being established to examine the ethical issues.

What is the difference between a committee and a working party? I do not want to listen to semantics from departmental officers when before a committee. I want to hear the clear truth. It was said that there was no committee. But a working party has been established and its terms and membership were included in the answer, which, in any event, I knew. But I am grateful for this being placed on the public record. I then asked:
Would not the Council-
that is, the National Health and Medical Research Council-
agree that the question of registers which record the names of patients and families in Australia with inherited disorders raises fundamental questions of direct interest to legislators?
The response was:
While the Department cannot comment on behalf of the NHMRC, it is noted that the NHMRC-
it dobbed the NHMRC in-
has recognised the need for an ethical framework.
The word `ethical' is underlined. The Department, I think properly, continued:
It would certainly be timely to consider any legislative implications once the issues have been identified.
I asked:
Just whom did the committee of inquiry consult with in their practically unpublicised investigations?
The response was:

A press release informing the public of the establishment of the Working-Party was issued on April this year . . . Reference was also made to the Working Party in the MREC's May Newsletter. The Department is informed that it is anticipated, in accordance with previous practice, that public submissions will be called for by the MREC. Ultimately it is expected that ethical guidelines will need to be prepared.

It is very significant that `ethical guidelines' and `ethical framework' are mentioned. There is no mention of legislation in that context because that is what is being done with all these questions. These are major questions of public policy. The pro-experimentation scientists and the Medical Research Ethics Committee establishment are trying to usurp them and ensure that these matters of major public policy do not come before the Parliament to be determined. My final questions were:
What is the envisaged purpose of creating these registers? Is it proposed that these registers will be integrated into one network?
The answer was:

The Department is informed that the purpose of creating registers is one of the topics being clarified by the MREC, and that in general, the primary purpose is to improve the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of genetic disorders.

I emphasise the word `prevention' because a prominent member of the working party is Professor David Danks of the Murdoch Institute for Research in Birth Defects. In submission No. 1 to the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, he declared precisely what he meant by `prevention' and what was clearly meant by `prevention' in that answer by the then Department of Health. I quote from page 3 of his submission to the Senate Select Committee:

At present the most effective strategy available for preventing birth defects is by diagnosis of the genetic disease in a foetus at 16 weeks gestation by a process called amniocentesis or at ten weeks by chorion villus sampling, followed by termination of a pregnancy that has proven to be affected by a serious genetic disease.

That is what is meant by `prevention'. In regard to treatment, in the same submission, Professor Danks, who, let us remember, is a member of the working party, under the heading `Gene therapy in the early embryo' said:

This would involve the insertion of a normal gene into a defective embryo to correct the genetic defect. This process is technically possible already and genes inserted into a one cell fertilised mouse egg have been shown to function satisfactorily in the mouse that is subsequently born. There is every reason to believe that the same process could be carried out in humans. However, there is a simple logical reason for arguing that this process will never be used in the treatment of human genetic disease. Couples who are at risk of having children with genetic disease run either 25% or 50% risks, never 100%. Consequently, one would need some way of distinguishing a fertilised egg-
he is really referring to a human embryo-

which will result in a normal child from one which would produce a baby with a disease. If this testing were available, then surely one would merely implant the fertilised egg which will produce a normal baby, and not use the defective fertilised egg. I do not believe that early embryo gene therapy needs serious consideration among the range of experimentation on early human embryos that may be desirable in the future.

We have to be very clear about what is being attempted. The Government, in its answers, has not explained what track we are going down. (Extension of time granted) The last time registers of genetic taints were established was in nazi Germany. A very interesting book by Robert Jay Lifton, entitled The Nazi Doctors, which I picked up in Washington only about a month ago while doing work in this area, describes the establishment in Germany in 1934 of registers, card indexes, of genetic taints-lists of families with known genetic disorders. We now know-they did not know then-that there are about 4,000 genetic disorders. None of us is really perfect. Which genetic disorders will be deemed to fit into the MREC's plan? That is not explained in the answers I have been given. In Germany people with genetic disorders were brought before courts, which were declared to be secret for the so-called protection of the people brought before them. As a result, according to Robert Jay Lifton, some 200,000 people were sterilised. Martin Bormann suggested that the criteria for sterilisation went to the question of whether a person had anti-state ideas.

Sterilisation probably is not what is proposed by the MREC establishment circles. What is being proposed is the establishment of a filtering system in which IVF and other processes will be used. Persons with histories of genetic disorders will be encouraged to have their early human embryos DNA-probed and, if they are deemed to be abnormal, action will be taken. As this is an Estimates examination, a full-scale debate on this matter cannot take place. The embryo experimentation scientists and their allies in the MREC are trying desperately to keep this question from the representatives of the people in the Parliament.

I ask the Minister what the bioethics unit of the Department of Community Services and Health is doing at present. Has it, for example, been involved in developing the legislation that is currently before the South Australian Parliament, which includes in its definition of `human reproductive material' semen and ovum-that is, the gametes-and a human embryo? That is interesting, is it not? How it can be scientifically sustained is beyond me. How can one include in a definition of `human reproductive material' a human embryo? Puberty comes pretty early these days, apparently. It is also beyond me how the whole question of human embryo experimentation can be sent off to a non-elected, appointed committee which is heavily loaded with medical and scientific personnel.

The Minister might be able to confirm whether she has been having discussions in South Australia about this matter or whether that is being done by the bioethics unit of the Department of Community Services and Health. She might be able to tell us whether the mature decisions and conclusions of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill with which I was not entirely happy have been drawn to the attention of the South Australian Government. Has their attention been drawn to the major finding of the Committee that there is a need for legislative protection of human embryos from destructive, non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrates their development from fertilisation onwards?

The other question I want to ask the Minister about the bioethics unit of the Department of Community Services and Health is whether it is proposed that the national committee adopt the recommendation proposed by the Senate Select Committee that it be bound by the statutory principle which would protect the human embryo from destructive, non-therapeutic experimentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Will the Minister reaffirm the undertaking given on behalf of the Government by the Prime Minister on 11 August that police officers appearing before the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody will be provided with legal assistance by the Government in the same way as assistance is to be provided to the relatives of those Aborigines who died in custody?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will have received representations from the Police Federation of Australia during the course of yesterday concerning the possible financial assistance to be given to that organisation and individual police officers from the States and the Northern Territory should they be required to appear or seek leave to appear before the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I had the pleasure of being called on yesterday by the National Secretary of the Federation and three delegates from its conference which was being held in Canberra, and we had a most amicable discussion, during which they put the sorts of requests which are inherent in Senator Chaney's question.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of those conversations, I immediately had discussions with Mr Gerry Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and I have had discussions with the office of the Prime Minister. I am able to say that the Government is disposed to respond favourably to any formal application for financial assistance by the Police Federation of Australia, should it be given leave to appear before Mr Justice Muirhead. The fact is the Federation is the peak body of the various associations and unions of police officers and personnel throughout Australia, and there is obviously a strong analogy between its position and that of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service as a national body. It is possibly, if I may say so, somewhat stronger in that it is the police officers and prison officers who may be in jeopardy as a result of the findings of the Commission. Should a formal request be made-and I emphasise that I am surprised to find that a formal request has not been made, but perhaps this is interlinked with whether leave to appear is given by Mr Justice Muirhead-I am able to say that the Government would look upon such formal request for financial assistance by that peak body very favourably.

As to individual police officers, I think that in this situation the Prime Minister-it may have been the Acting Prime Minister in the absence of the Prime Minister overseas-wrote to the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory in order to ascertain from them what joint funding might be undertaken in relation to the Royal Commission, it being a fact that the Royal Commission is supported by joint arrangements between the Federal Government, the State governments and the Government of the Northern Territory. That exchange of letters initiated by the Acting Prime Minister goes to the question of cost sharing and of State governments funding the legal costs associated with the appearance of their officials before the Royal Commission. At the moment, to my knowledge, only two have responded-the Premier of Western Australia and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Until all of those replies are in and State Premiers give an indication of their preparedness to support some of the costs associated with the Royal Commission and the provision of financial assistance to their police officers-I include prison officers and other custodial personnel-it is somewhat premature to make any undertaking on behalf of the Federal Government. In fact, in all other royal commissions of which I can think the States have normally borne the responsibility for the appearance of their officials, and I would think that most States will respond with that precedent in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response and welcome the positive nature of it. However, I seek some clarification. I think that the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service, in addition to being a peak body with its own role before the Royal Commission, will also undertake the task of distributing financial assistance to individual families, but I am not sure about that. —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and relates to the level of public sector expenditure on current transfer payments in Australia. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a copy of the speech which Mr Wran delivered two days ago, on Monday. In using the term `current transfer payments', he was referring principally to social security pensions and other social security payments such as unemployment benefits, current grants to non-profit organisations and public debt interest-in other words, those Commonwealth expenditures which are just transferred to other persons or bodies in the non-government sector. It is worth quoting the key paragraph in Mr Wran's speech, which was:

ANSWER.PARA: In the result, as a proportion of GDP, Australia doesn't spend a lot on public sector activities compared with other developed democratic countries.
Indeed, if one looks at government expenditures on transfer payments, for instance, only Iceland and Turkey spent proportionately less than Australia.

I have checked out the figures used in that claim by Mr Wran and, on the most recent data available to me, I can confirm that they are correct. I have here a table of the majority of OECD countries which shows the percentage of gross domestic product which is transfer payments; and in the calendar year 1984, Iceland had 9.2 per cent and Australia 16.5 per cent. The highest figure was that of the Netherlands, at 39.7 per cent, which is more than double the Australian level. I seek leave to have that table incorporated in Hansard.
CURRENT TRANSFER PAYMENTS* AS A PERCENTAGE OF GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT FOR SELECTED OECD COUNTRIES

* Calculated as the difference between current expenditure on goods and services and current disbursements, where current disbursements comprise current expenditure on goods and services plus current transfers and payment of property income.
** Uses latest available data which for most countries is 1984-85.
Sources: OECD, Economic Survey of Netherlands, Paris, March, 1986. OECD, Economic Survey of Germany, Paris, June 1983. OECD, National Accounts, 1986 Edition.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, what Mr Wran said is certainly confirmed by the available statistics but, as Mr Wran did say, that does not mean that we should not be continually striving to make the public sector more effective and efficient. The claim that Mr Wran made and the figures which confirm his claim show quite decisively that the propaganda of what has come to be called the New Right about the size of the public sector in Australia being too big is clearly nonsense. In fact there is no identifiable correlation between the size of the public sector and any index of economic performance or economic efficiency. To that should be added, of course, the point that those countries that have a very high proportion of transfer payments-countries such as Belgium, the Netherlands, the Scandinavian countries, Italy, France and so on-also have a level of taxation which is commensurate with the level of public expenditure. The figures destroy the myth being peddled by the Andrew Hays, the Ian McLachlans and, of course, the John Stones of this world.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the answer he gave on 17 November to my question about a breach by him of an undertaking given by his predecessor, Mr Duffy, concerning the confidentiality of information on the advertising revenue of radio stations. The Minister will recall that he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I have not yet had an opportunity to see for myself what the terms of that original communication-
that, of course, was Mr Duffy's letter to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-
might have been and to satisfy myself that what I did say publicly may arguably have been at odds with it.

Has the Minister considered the matter further and does he now agree that he breached the undertaking given by Mr Duffy? In view of the fact that the information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to Mr Duffy was conditional on the assurance that the information would not be published or divulged in any way, has the Minister received any subsequent views from the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal on the Minister's breach of confidentiality? If so, what are those views? Further, is it a fact that the Government's establishment fee system will make it more difficult for the Broadcasting Tribunal to obtain much needed information from broadcasters-in addition to that information which is presently required to be supplied under the Broadcasting Act, given that the information is provided on an in confidence basis because of the commercial sensitivities of it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had an opportunity to look at the relevant correspondence on this. It is clear that Mr Duffy gave an undertaking of confidentiality. That was in a very different context, of course, from that which has been involved in recent times where the matter at issue has been the fee payable for the establishment of a new licence and the basis for the calculation of that. The particular context in which Mr Duffy was responding was that of information required for planning purposes, and, in particular, to determine those markets in respect of which either new licences or supplementary licences, as the case may be, would be called for. Obviously, in a planning context detailed information as to the financial performance of particular licensees was highly sensitive. It was in that context that Mr Duffy gave that undertaking.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, I was not aware of that undertaking when I gave the information that I did at the time of announcing the establishment fee system. That was in the context of identifying the gross earnings from the particular service areas in question as a basis for enabling people interested in the new licence fee system to know in general terms-I did not express it with any great precision-what they would be up for so far as the establishment fee was concerned. The new legislation will make it perfectly clear that there can be no confidentiality in respect of that class of information. It is at odds with the whole purpose of the legislation, which is designed to set an establishment fee based on the revenue performance of the area in question. I regret that there was an inadvertent breach by me of what could be seen as an undertaking relevant to the present circumstances as well as to the previous ones. I hope that in all the circumstances that will be understood, and the reasons why it occurred will be appreciated.

I have had a communication from Miss O'Connor on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal because she is understandably concerned about her capacity to continue to get confidential information if there is any risk of that confidentiality being breached. I explained in a letter in reply the particular circumstances which led to that happening-the very different context in which the information was sought and given publicly-and referred to the fact that the legislation will create a different regime for this in the future. I hope that on the basis of that the matter can be appropriately closed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FITZGERALD INQUIRY INTO QUEENSLAND POLICE FORCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I ask the Minister whether his attention has been drawn to widespread publicity given to remarks made by the Queensland Health and Environment Minister, Mr Mike Ahern, that attempts by Premier Bjelke-Petersen to remove Police Minister Bill Gunn and others are directly related to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct? In view of the widespread public suspicion that attempts will be made by the Queensland Government to at least muzzle the Fitzgerald inquiry, will he assure the Senate that the National Crime Authority (NCA) will make available to that inquiry all information that it has on organised crime, drug dealing, vice, illegal gambling and SP betting in Queensland, whether or not it involves politicians, judges or others in high places? What measures are in place or are contemplated for liaison and information exchange between the National Crime Authority and the Fitzgerald inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to comments made by the Queensland Health and Environment Minister, Mr Mike Ahern, that he believed that the attempt to dismiss, in particular, the Police Minister, Mr Bill Gunn, from the Queensland Ministry was in fact linked to his, and no doubt the Premier's, premonitions about the outcome and the course of proceedings of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry. Senator Jones asked whether the NCA will undertake and is undertaking inquiries covering much the same ground as the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry. I have already indicated to the Senate that the National Crime Authority has a joint reference with the Queensland Government where a number of matters overlap with those currently being examined by the Fitzgerald inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think I have told the Senate before, but in fact the National Crime Authority reference-when I say `reference', I mean that there is available to the Authority plenary and extraordinary powers beyond those normally available to police forces in Australia-includes matters such as the cultivation and supply of Indian hemp, drugs of addiction and other prohibited drugs, illegal gambling, extortion, threats of violence, violence, murder, attempted murder and conspiracy to murder. So from the outset of the Fitzgerald inquiry there obviously has been much common ground between the two bodies in regard to the material they are investigating. Further, I can assure the Senate on the basis of advice I have received from the National Crime Authority that it has actively sought to assist the Fitzgerald inquiry. In fact, Mr Fitzgerald has written to me thanking me for the prompting and urging which I have given to the Federal law enforcement agencies, including the NCA and the Australian Federal Police, in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well deserved.

—I thank the honourable senator. There is close and continuing co-operation at the highest levels between the Fitzgerald inquiry and the National Crime Authority on matters of mutual interest. The National Crime Authority is providing its assistance to the Fitzgerald inquiry in a timely and useful way. Further, I can also advise the Senate of development over the last week or so in that the Assistant Commissioner, Operations, of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter Lamb, has, with the agreement of Major-General Grey, the Australian Federal Police Commissioner, held extensive discussions with the Fitzgerald inquiry in recent days. As a result the Federal Police will be actively assisting the Commission of Inquiry through its extensive international officer liaison network and will undertake inquiries in Australia in relation, in particular, to tracing the movements of cash.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in today's Australian newspaper indicating that the Western Australian Department of Agriculture plant breeding program has succeeded, where Europe, Canada and China have failed, in developing a strain of rape seed which is not only polyunsaturated but also has a longer storage life than traditional oils. In light of this substantial achievement by an Australian public plant breeding body, and in light of a further report in the same newspaper indicating that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation might be added to the list of privatisation targets, will the Minister give a commitment that, now that Australia has plant variety rights like many of those other, unsuccessful, countries in this project, our efficient and effective public breeding sector will not lose funding or be privatised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report. I do not know whether it is correct or not although, given the record of the newspaper in which it is published, I would like to have some independent corroboration before I accept it as being correct. Assuming it is correct, Senator Powell seems to have concluded with the sort of logic which is characteristic of the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party that, because one country has plant variety rights legislation or has had in the past, and another country has not, everything in the outcome of plant breeding in those countries is attributable to that difference. The reference to plant variety rights reminded me that Senator Powell was one of the passionate opponents of plant variety rights, along with all the rest of the Lygon Street farmers, who have two factors in common: one a propensity to swallow conspiracy theories and the other a profound ignorance of agriculture.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked whether I will give any guarantees that public breeding institutions will not lose funding. No, I will not give any such guarantee, although I know that the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party believes, among other things, that people should get two pensions and free board and lodging as well. It is not responsible for any Finance Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —No economic growth. You must not have any economic growth.

—And no economic growth, yes-and an increasing population. They might not believe in that, but that is happening anyway. That, therefore, means a steady decline in per capita real income. I will not give any such assurance. Indeed, it would not be responsible for a Finance Minister to give those sorts of assurances because a competing claim for limited government funds should be assessed on its own merits and against the judgment of the total availability of government funds at any particular time.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer her to an article in the Business Review Weekly of 6 November entitled `Bureaucratic Push May Backfire'. Will the Minister comment on assertions in that article that, firstly, reporting requirements under the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act will put unreasonable pressure on business and that, secondly, child care will become a business responsibility under the Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to respond to Senator Crowley's question by saying that the claims made in that article are quite unfounded. The Affirmative Action Agency, in response to requests for assistance from industry, undertook earlier this year a pilot test of a draft public report format for reports required under the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act. The draft report format was piloted with 10 companies from a representative cross-section of industry. After a thorough process of review and evaluation many sections of the public report were either deleted or significantly changed in the final format and, in particular, the questions quoted in the Business Review Weekly article have either been deleted or substantially changed. The final format provides companies with the opportunity to describe the processes they underwent in implementing their affirmative action programs. It specifically states that companies are free to adapt it to suit their needs.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is important for the Senate to realise that the Affirmative Action Agency has taken meticulous care to fulfil its responsibility to consult with business on issues relating to the development and implementation of affirmative action and especially to avoid the imposition of any unreasonable pressure on business. The work-related child care study also referred to in the article is not intended to enforce child care on employers and has no connection with the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act. It is being undertaken by the Office of the Status of Women to facilitate the dissemination of information to employers, unions and community groups about work-related child care and it is being overseen by a steering committee representing, among others, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to previous answers he has given the Senate on the alarming increase in industrial unrest in the steel industry, answers which, stripped of their rhetoric, boil down to the fact that he and the Government refuse to take any direct action to tackle the problem of union disruption of the steel plan, particularly at the Port Kembla works. Has the Minister seen the report, which I hold up, tabled yesterday in the House of Representatives from that chamber's Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, chaired by a Government member and with a Government majority, which strongly criticises the failure of the unions to meet their commitments under the steel plan? Has he further noted the Committee's concern that the Steel Industry Authority is no longer monitoring union adherence to the plan and that the Authority has not been effective in halting the escalating level of industrial disputation? I ask whether the Government supports the Committee's conclusion that:

QUESTION.PARA: Unless the unions are prepared to meet their commitments, the benefits of the plan can quickly be eroded. It is now up to the national union bodies to become more involved and to obtain greater commitments from its members.
Finally, will the Government bring pressure on the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to obtain those commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Lewis is taking advantage of Question Time in order to attack me. That is a dreadful abuse of Question Time. It is a dreadful thing for any member of the Opposition to do. I answer his question feeling somewhat aggrieved and hurt by the tone in which he addressed this question to me.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen the report which the honourable senator has brandished, but I have seen some reports of it. I more or less know what is in it. The honourable senator draws certain conclusions from it. I cannot comment directly on the middle part of his very long speech, but I do broadly agree with the conclusions of the Committee. If I can help the honourable senator in this sense, let me state what I think the point of his question is and then answer it. The point of the question is that the honourable senator suggests, first of all, that the Government refuses to take direct action against the unions concerned. I think the honourable senator means the Port Kembla branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. Yes, that has been so. The Government does not see benefits for the industry in its interfering directly in the relationship between the employers and the employees in the Port Kembla steel industry. In the last six months there have been proceedings in the New South Wales Industrial Tribunal to deregister the Port Kembla branch of the Ironworkers Association. With those proceedings in train, it would certainly not be proper for the Government to intervene in that matter. We were informed of that action being taken by the company, as was the Steel Industry Authority.

In answering a question earlier I said that on 28 October the steel industry met with both the unions and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) regarding the industrial relations problems-not the other problems-at Port Kembla. I do not know when the Committee wrote that report, but I would not think that the speed of publication here would have enabled it to have taken into account that meeting on 28 October or what has happened since. Yesterday or the day before the Australian Council of Trade Unions had a meeting with the company to discuss these issues at Port Kembla. As I have said to Senator Lewis on a number of other occasions, I think that although the situation is difficult at Port Kembla, in the words of a BHP spokesman, it is improving, and I do not think it should be exacerbated or the possibility for an improving situation should be made worse-I cannot think of the correct word--

TALK.START.PARA: —Exacerbated.

—Exacerbated, if you like-I thank the honourable senator-by heavy rhetoric from a Government spokesman or, indeed, from the Liberals in the House of Representatives or in the Senate. I think we should just let these matters take their course for a week or two. I think it is important that there has been ACTU intervention in the matter. I am hopeful there will be a successful outcome. If there is not, other steps may have to be taken.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to the Government's policy on assessment of geriatrics. Is the development of geriatric assessment procedures a major priority in the community services portfolio in order to help contain the spiralling costs of aged care in Australia? What progress has been made toward the implementation of geriatric assessment in Queensland? Would geriatric assessment be available, for example, in that State for a person such as a New Zealand born 76-year-old male peanut farmer and public sector executive?

—Senator Maguire will be pleased to hear that care of Australia's aged population is a high priority in the Department of Community Services and Health. Nursing homes are for people who require 24-hour nursing care. Only a small number of elderly people fall into this category. Appropriate assessment of older people is the key to ensuring that nursing home care is available to those who really need it. Those who do not are assisted to find more appropriate forms of care. To help achieve these ends, the Commonwealth is piloting in Victoria and the Northern Territory the granting to assessment services of the authority to approve nursing home admission. Queensland has been one of the slower States to respond to the development of assessment services. Currently the Commonwealth is funding assessment services in Toowoomba, south-west Queensland, Cairns, Maryborough and Nambour. Ministerial approval is about to be sought for the funding of services in Townsville, Mackay, Roma, Charleville, north Brisbane and south Brisbane. So it is fair to say that the Commonwealth is certainly making what contribution it can to the assessment of geriatric care needs in Queensland and the rest of Australia.

—Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the National Assembly of Thailand, led by His Excellency the President of the Senate, Dr Ukrit Mongkolnavin. On behalf of all senators I extend to the delegation a warm welcome and trust that their stay in Australia is a success.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Government aware of the results of a recent authoritative poll conducted in Moscow by a French polling organisation which showed that 53 per cent of people favoured a total withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, with only 27 per cent opposed? Is it a fact that, despite Mr Gorbachev's July 1985 Vladivostok promise and regular renewed Soviet commitments thereafter, there has been only a cosmetic recycling of troop numbers? In these circumstances is it true, as I have been reliably informed, that the Prime Minister, on the advice of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, has decided not to include the question of Afghanistan on the agenda for his forthcoming trip to the Soviet Union? If this is so, will the Government publicly explain the reasons for this pusillanimous approach? Otherwise, will the Government give a firm and unequivocal commitment to maintaining public and diplomatic pressure on the Soviet Union so that the five million Afghan refugees who constitute a third of the world's total refugee population will be able to return to their native country as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of the substance, if any, to the suggestion about the removal of this item from the agenda for the talks. I will seek information from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Prime Minister and advise accordingly. But what I can say is that it is absolute nonsense to suggest that Australia, both publicly and privately, has not been mounting a very vigorous and continued campaign, if one wants to put it in those terms, and certainly expressing views very vigorously on the situation in Afghanistan.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Alston, who prides himself on following such matters very closely, that Australia's permanent representative to the United Nations in New York delivered Australia's statement on Afghanistan to the forty-second session of the United Nations General Assembly on 9 November, just two or three weeks ago, during the General Assembly's annual debate on that subject. He announced Australia's intention to support Pakistan's draft resolution calling for the withdrawal of all Soviet forces from Afghanistan, as we have done since the resolution was first moved in 1980. In doing that, the Australian statement condemned in the strongest terms the continuing occupation of Afghanistan. It laid the blame for the sad plight of the Afghan people directly at the door of the Soviet Union. It called for an early political solution which would permit the Afghan people to exercise their fundamental right of self-determination.

The statement sought to encourage the Soviet Union to take concrete steps to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan, noting that no delegation would be happier than Australia's if the Afghan item subsequently were able to be withdrawn from the General Assembly's agenda. It pointed out that genuine movements in the near future by the Soviet Union toward a political settlement in Afghanistan could accelerate the process upon which Australia has embarked recently of improving its relations and broadening the base of its contacts with the Soviet Union. There could not be a more explicit condemnation of the situation than that, combined with some constructive suggestions as to how the solution of the problem might be advanced. It is absolute nonsense to suggest, as Senator Alston has done, that there has been some back-pedalling or resistance on the part of the Australian Government to pursuing this matter openly and vigorously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from the tone of the Minister's response that, come the next anniversary of the Soviet invasion, 27 December next, the Foreign Minister will be prepared to specifically condemn the Soviet invasion, although he has specifically refused to do so on earlier anniversaries?

—I have no idea what the situation will be come the next anniversary of the invasion. All I can say is that the claim that the Foreign Minister has failed to condemn has been the subject of previous debate in this place and when the allegation has been raised it has been shown to be absolutely false. The Opposition has been twisting things out of context and generally utterly misrepresenting the very strong position this Government and its Foreign Minister have consistently taken.

—Has the attention of the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a letter in the September issue of News, the journal of the national Epilepsy Association of Australia, in which a Dr Andrew Black, medical adviser to the Epilepsy Association of South Australia, criticises the changes made to the rebate to patients for visits to private specialist consultant physicians. The letter implies that people suffering epilepsy and other chronic illnesses are being treated unfairly and may be put at risk by the change. Can the Minister comment on the points raised in the letter? Has Dr Black given an accurate outline of the changes to the schedule and the likely effect on patients of these changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, Dr Black's account of the situation concerning the Government's reasons for changing the payment of Medicare benefits for epilepsy is very misleading. It is disappointing that somebody in Dr Black's position and with his responsibility has used his position so as to mislead and alarm those people with epilepsy. Contrary to what Dr Black claims, the 1 August changes to consultant physician fees were not designed to change the way epilepsy is managed. In fact, they were designed to match fees and benefits with changes in patient management practices which have already occurred. Changes to Medicare fees and benefits for the fourth and subsequent visits to consultant physicians were made to reflect far more accurately the consultant physician's role as it has evolved in modern medical practice.

ANSWER.PARA: Fees for visits to consultant physicians were originally structured in recognition of the special role the physicians play in the diagnosing and stabilising of conditions, and as the providers of higher medical opinion. Over time, however, consultant physicians have moved increasingly into the provision of ongoing care and patient management. While the Government is not saying that it is inappropriate for it to provide ongoing care, we believe that in this case the fees should be adjusted accordingly. Thus, from the fourth visit to a consultant physician for a particular episode, the fee drops back to the rate currently paid for specialists who provide similar ongoing care. Discussions have been held since, between the Department and representatives of consultant physicians, to examine any possible anomalies in the system. The physicians have proposed the introduction of a new system involving major and minor consultations. Discussions are continuing about this. However, Dr Black's suggestion that if the August change does result in reduced costs this somehow will be unfair to epileptics and others with chronic illnesses is ludicrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health to the answer which the Minister for Community Services and Health gave to a question in the House of Representatives in which Dr Blewett condemned the Northern Territory Government over the establishment of a private hospital within a public hospital campus in Darwin. This was an interim measure pending the completion of a new building for a private hospital. Given the Health Minister's warning that this decision has major policy implications, does this warning also apply to all State governments and, in particular, the New South Wales Government regarding its proposals to introduce similar private hospitals within the St George hospital, the Lismore hospital and, possibly, the Campbelltown hospital? Does the Government intend also to close the private division already operating in the Calvary public hospital located in Canberra, which would be well known to Senator Ryan?

—The answer to the last part of Senator Tambling's question is no. As to his other questions arguing some sort of relationship between the policy in regard to the Northern Territory and possible policies in relation to New South Wales hospitals, I will refer those to Dr Blewett.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the nature of the Minister's answer, very emphatically, to the latter part of my question relating to the Calvary public hospital in Canberra in which she indicated that there would be no intention to close the private division, will she please draw a comparison between that situation and the situation at Royal Darwin Hospital?
—I will seek further information from Dr Blewett.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen Steve Burrell's article in the Sydney Morning Herald of today headlined `Despite Joh's bluster, Queensland is a mess'? Is it true that-I quote the article-`of the 18 key economic indicators released up to October this year, Queensland has the worst result in six, the second worst in five, and was below the national average in 13'? What effect does the wallowing of the economy of the State represented by Senator Stone have on the national results? How does Queensland compare with Western Australia, another mining and agricultural State? Would a prices and incomes accord approach such as the one operated by this Government have a positive effect on Queensland's economic performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that it is actually fair to blame Senator Stone for the state of the Queensland economy.
—He has just moved up there.

—Yes, he has not been there long enough to have had much effect on it. I am sure that Senator Stone would not share all of the eccentricities of the Queensland Premier. For example, I understand that in his youth he was a student of nuclear physics and he would therefore not believe that a fusion reactor could be put into the boot of a motor car to generate electricity for the hydrolysis of water and then an internal combustion engine could be run on the hydrogen gas produced. I am sure that even though it is a very long time since Senator Stone was a student of nuclear physics he would not believe that as the Queensland Premier did. I doubt that he would believe that Milan Brych had a cure for cancer either, or that water will run uphill.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen Steve Burrell's article. It is obvious that he has been studying either the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) bulletins or the Senate Hansards because he uses the sort of economic statistics which have been published by the ABS over the last year or so and to which the attention of the Senate has been drawn from time to time by questions from Senator Maguire and various Queensland senators, and probably by Senator Cook before. I have been asked what the comparison is between Queensland and Western Australia. I cannot remember off the top of my head all the figures but I do recall that Western Australia had the highest rate of private investment in the most recent financial year for which statistics are available; Queensland had the lowest. I think the same is also true for employment growth, even though the economies of the two States are probably more similar than the economy of either State is to that of any other State.

As well as the summary which Senator Cook mentioned in his question, the article shows-to the best of my recollection these figures are all correct, as indeed I would expect them to be-that the unemployment rate in October in Queensland was 9.9 per cent compared with a national average of 8.2 per cent; that the job vacancy rate in August was 0.5 per cent, which is the lowest for any State; that employment growth in the year to October was 1.1 per cent, only half of the national figure; that retail sales in the year to September were the lowest at 6.9 per cent compared with a national figure of 8.1 per cent; and so on. Indeed, as one goes through the statistics one finds that almost without exception Queensland has turned in either the worst performance or the second worst performance. As this article says:
Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's successor will inherit an economy which has performed consistently worse than the national average over the past four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to recent newspaper reports that three northern New South Wales enterprises funded by the Aboriginal Development Commission have recently failed-the most recent being the Oasis Hotel at Walgett, which is expected to go into receivership despite grant moneys of some $900,000 being poured into it. Given that the ADC operates on a national budget of nearly $100m annually and given the criticism expressed by many in the community that little study is done into the business worth of many of the projects selected for funding, I ask whether the Department plans to review its selection criteria for future projects. How does the Government justify this apparently careless use of taxpayers' funds? Can the Minister attribute the reason for default by borrowers of taxpayers' money to lack of asset backing, market changes, management and staff training difficulties or failure to seek expert advice?

—Senator Brownhill has asked several questions concerning the relationship of the funding by the Aboriginal Development Commission to the Department's responsibility for the expenditure of money on various projects in northern New South Wales. I am not absolutely clear as to whether the Commission is sufficiently independent or autonomous for its own officers to make that judgment rather than the Department make the assessment which lies behind the thrust of Senator Brownhill's question. I think I will need to clarify that relationship of the Department and the Aboriginal Development Commission before I can usefully answer the question in its various parts. I do know that when the-I think it was-Chief Executive Officer of the Aboriginal Development Commission appeared before the Estimates committee, he was subjected to a very thorough examination by Senator Tambling, amongst others. Insofar as the honourable senator asked questions relating to specific projects in northern New South Wales, I will have to refer those to the Minister for reply.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a distinguished former senator, Stan Collard. Stan must be popular. I have had five reminders from honourable senators on both sides of the chamber that he is sitting there. On behalf of all senators, therefore, I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

—I also welcome Stan Collard. We are delighted to see him back here on the other side. My question is to the Minister for Justice. Has the Minister seen Press reports that the Launceston office of the Australian Federal Police will close? Can he inform the Senate of the reasons for this decision? Does he intend to review that decision himself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to reports that the office of the Australian Federal Police in Launceston is to be closed. I must say that I first heard of this last night. I think it was Mr Warwick Smith, the Federal member for Bass in the other place, who wrote to me about this matter. I immediately put out a Press release which, amongst other things, made these comments:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . decisions about deployment of the Federal Police in Tasmania would be made on strict operational grounds. . . . the Federal Police Commissioner, Major General Grey, had responsibility for the deployment of his force throughout Australia.
Any decision he makes on the Launceston office would be taken on strict operational grounds, and I have no intention of politically influencing his decision.
The fight against drug trafficking and major fraud against the Commonwealth is too important to be bedevilled by Ministers playing politics as to where the force is deployed . . .
Having made that very general statement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Walters laughs at my attitude that the proper deployment of forces is the operational responsibility of the Commissioner. If she thinks it is all right for politicians to interfere in the deployment of those forces, she should say so. I will be pleased to have a debate on it. I happen not to agree with her point of view. This morning I received a fuller briefing. It is quite clear from an assessment made by Assistant Commissioner Winchester, whose responsibilities include the Tasmania region, that any decision to close the Launceston station would be sufficiently well based, I believe, to satisfy those members-and even those members of the northern Tasmanian community-who may have misgivings and worries about this matter. The briefing document from Deputy Commissioner Johnson reads:

ANSWER.PARA: Assistant Commissioner Winchester reported that-from an examination of the work load of functions being performed at Launceston it was evident to him, when compared against AFP priorities, that the resource commitment of the station could not be justified. Apart from very minor fraud related inquiries and some intelligence gathering exercises, the work load was found to be negligible. Whilst there is a Family Law Court commitment, when it is in session, this service could be provided as required from Hobart.
The objective of closing the station is not a cost saving exercise but rather a more efficient deployment of personnel to higher priority work.

Because I am always very conscious of the Federal police officers union, I might say that the proposal to close the Launceston station has been accepted by the Australian Federal Police Association. So there we have it: the decision has been made on operational grounds. It appears to be well based. Even if it were not as well based as it is, I would not seek to exercise political influence in relation to its deployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a wonderful Tasmanian Minister!

—Senator Walters thinks that because I am Tasmanian I should take a parochial attitude and deploy Federal police in a way which prevents them from more effectively fighting organised crime and drug trafficking around Australia. That is not my attitude. I do not believe that the honourable senator's attitude is shared by senators on either side of the chamber.

Does the Minister concede that the Government has no right to place any such restrictions on service spouses as, like other Australians, they are entitled to approach any parliamentarian as they wish?

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. In view of the topicality of immigration and the extraordinarily exclusive attitudes of two National Party senators, can the Minister give an account of the measures taken by the Hawke Government in recognition of the needs of migrant women and the great contribution which they make to Australian society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike some elements in this place, the Government greatly appreciates the contribution made by migrants, including immigrant women, and recognises the need for special services to enable their participation of Australian society to be as full as they would wish it to be. It is the Government's intention that immigrant women, and women from non-English speaking backgrounds, benefit from the activities undertaken by the Government, in respect of both immigrants as a whole and women. The Office of the Status of Women and the Office of Multicultural Affairs aim to respond to the needs and concerns of immigrant and non-English speaking women. As examples of the special steps taken to that end, I remind the Senate of recent allocations from the Office of the Status of Women, including financial assistance for a special conference to provide an overview of areas of special concern to women from non-English backgrounds, as part of the National Agenda for Women. In 1986 the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils was granted $15,000 to employ an ethnic women's project officer to establish a national women's ethnic network. In 1986-87, $25,000 was allocated to the Illawarra Area Health Service, which has an area migrant health team, to investigate women's social and mental health and $8,280 was allocated to the ecumenical migration centre to assist in the needs of Vietnamese single mothers.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as these specific projects, the Government's access and equity strategy seeks to ensure that all immigrants have access to an equitable share of Government programs and services. Part of this strategy has been to direct all departments to take action to identify and serve the needs of immigrant and non-English speaking women. One specific area for focus is immigrant women in rural areas. The Office of Multicultural Affairs has funded a project which is aimed at identifying the needs of immigrant and non-English speaking women in the Mildura area. The settlement needs of immigrant women are specifically addressed by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs women's and advising section. This section is responsible for monitoring and advising on the activities of the Department with regard to women. These are, of course, only some examples of the special steps taken to ensure that migrant women have, as far as possible, equal opportunity both to benefit from the services available in Australia and to contribute to and participate in Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the Minister to the Attorney-General's appointment of a consultative group to assist him in the development of planned national companies legislation. Is the Minister aware of the widespread opposition in the small business sector to the Government's proposal to abolish the current co-operative companies and securities scheme and replace it with a centralised commission under the control of the Federal Attorney-General? Does the Minister agree with small business organisations which have criticised the proposal because it will deny them access to decision makers in the corporate affairs area and because the level of services in each State will decline? In light of those concerns, will the Minister request the Attorney-General to appoint representatives of small business to his advisory group, which currently numbers 34 but has no representative of small business, or will he stand by and allow big government, big business and big unions access to bulldoze small business again?
—Excellent question.
—Co-operativism at its best.

—I would be interested if Senator Crichton-Browne would put his view about this issue in a debate at some time. If he is in favour of intense regulation under a Federal system, I am sure he will adopt the view which is inherent in Senator McGauran's question.
—I believe in Federal co-operativism.

—Perhaps at some time Senator Crichton-Browne can articulate what that means. If I might say so, it would be a formidable challenge. I am not aware of the extent of so-called widespread opposition to the proposals contained in the Attorney-General's discussion paper. In light of that statement, I cannot assess the validity or otherwise of the concerns which Senator McGauran says are being expressed by small business organisations. My experience with some of the small business organisations is that there has been a crisis of misunderstanding or a failure to understand certain changes in Government policies, more than anything else. The point of Senator McGauran's question, aided as it was by the gusty interjection of Senator Boswell, was whether I would ask the Attorney-General to look at having some representatives of small business on his advisory group. I will do that. I would probably also advise the Attorney- General that, in appointing representatives of small businesses, he should not indulge in their habit of self-appointed representatives of small business. As the honourable senator well knows, there are a number of organisations of that kind.
—Name them.
—What does the honourable senator think this is? I will draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Attorney-General and see what his reaction is.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy a series of questions in relation to the pollution of Australian food, in this case pollution with cadmium and not with chlorinated hydrocarbons. Is the Minister aware that Australian soils are polluted with cadmium to very high levels and that this element is being augmented by the addition of superphosphate, the phosphate coming from ocean islands? Is the Minister aware that the national residue survey for 1986 showed that 10 per cent of the wheat examined exceeded the permitted levels of cadmium? Did Sweden reject a shipment of Australian wheat as long as 10 years ago on the grounds of excessive cadmium contamination? Does Sweden currently not import Australian wheat on those grounds? Did the national residue survey of 1986 also show that 21 per cent of sheep kidneys and 12 per cent of beef kidneys exceeded the maximum permissible level of 2.5 milligrams of cadmium per kilogram? Incidentally, nearly 75 per cent of sheep kidneys in Western Australia exceeded that level. What is the Minister doing to publicise the hazards of cadmium intake and to reduce the levels of cadmium in Australian food?

—I think Senator Coulter would be as surprised as anybody else if I actually answered all those questions and, therefore, basically I will take them on notice. But I wish to say a couple of things. I am certainly not aware that Sweden has ever rejected a cargo of Australian wheat for any reason, but what he said may be so. I am not aware of the residue report of 1986. It is a long time since I have personally looked in any detail at these things, but I am aware of cadmium and I think the association with superphosphate is correct. But, firstly, having never lived in Lygon Street and, secondly, having been a practising farmer for nearly a quarter of a century--
—Lygon Street?
—The Australian Democrats agricultural wing comes from Lygon Street. They are known derisively by agricultural economists of my acquaintance as Lygon Street farmers.
—Mung beans and health food shops are the closest they ever get to cultivation.

—Yes, mung beans and health food shops and fairies at the bottom of the garden. But having been a practising farmer-and I know that superphosphate is not the only source of phosphate-I can assure Senator Coulter that if one tries to grow wheat, particularly on the sandier, loamier and gravelly soils of the Western Australian wheat belt, without using any superphosphate, and if superphosphate has not been used before, one does not even get one's seed back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to supplement an answer to a question I gave to Senator Alston earlier today about the Australian position on Afghanistan and whether or not the matter would be raised in Moscow. According to my advice, it has never been suggested that the matter not be on the Moscow agenda. ANSWER.PARA: . . . I and the Foreign Minister have condemned what is happening in Afghanistan, condemned the occupation by Soviet authorities in Afghanistan. We have done so time after time, and when I am in Moscow in less than a fortnight I shall be doing so again.
