TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator McLean asked me a supplementary question relating to payment of patient contributions by veterans receiving nursing home care because of war-caused disabilities. I have some supplementary information for him. The Government's compassion towards veterans with war-caused disabilities has not lessened, nor has its commitment to the ex-service community as a whole wavered. In the 1987-88 Budget, allocations to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio have increased by 14.15 per cent in health programs and by 12.9 per cent overall despite the intense pressure on the Government to reduce spending. These increases in the health programs are necessary and are a demonstration of the Government's commitment. Nevertheless, in the current climate, increases in Government spending, however, necessary, can only be sustained if every possible saving is made in areas where existing levels of expenditure cannot be justified. The levels of service and compensatory pension paid to totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners are compassionate, fair and equitable. The levels of nursing and medical care provided to these pensioners when they are admitted to nursing homes are also fair, compassionate and equitable. However, the Government considers that their exemption from the patient contribution is inequitable in terms of other residents, including other veterans and war widows, who are not similarly relieved of any part of the costs of daily living when they are admitted to nursing home care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Yesterday the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who represents the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), gave an unasked for departmental response in amplification of her answer to my question of the day before. Apart from not answering the question, the Minister has misrepresented my question and imputed improper motives to it. The editorial in today's Australian completely misrepresents my short question, which I will now repeat. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: When half a million Australians have difficulty in speaking English, why is the Government adding to this number by bringing in at least 40,000 migrants yearly with little or no English? I stress that they are migrants, not refugees. Why is the knowledge of English not a criterion prior to migrant entry? Why does the Government select migrants who have little or no English, thereby causing Australian taxpayers to fund tuition in English to the tune of some $50m a year?

Subsequent reporting in all the media has distorted the debate and shows that the latent racism in the media and the minds of those who attacked me is unjustified. It appears to me that freedom of speech has been badly jolted over the past few days and that freedom of the Press has been taken as irresponsible licence.

It was a perfectly legitimate question with regard to Government expenditure, but the media particularly have distorted and twisted it in an outrageous way. For example, the question is not `racist', as claimed, and in no way suggests that proficiency in English should be a criterion, let alone the sole criterion, for migrant selection. The question merely suggests that after selection and prior to entry migrants should attempt to learn English. Again, there was no suggestion of language testing or reference to their `funny clothes or different habits', as appeared in the Australian Financial Review. The Australian slithered quickly from `ability to speak English' to having a `full command of English'. Moreover, in my view it is undemocratic to have half a million people unable to take part in our democracy because they cannot speak English.

To claim that there is no fundamental racial problem in California or Hawaii is specious, as is the claim that the main problem there is black-white and nothing to do with immigration. The problem in the United States of America at the moment is illegal immigration, on top of everything else, but it has nothing to do with my question. The media say that I have contributed to stirring up the worst in people, creating problems where none exist; that I am an opponent of large scale immigration from a diverse range of nations; and that I used intemperate language producing a polarised emotional slanging match. I ask members of the media to read my question again, if they ever read it at all.

The complete misrepresentation of what I actually said is astonishing, and the journalists concerned have shown a lack of professionalism. Added to the abuse of me, Senator Stone has been vilified by the media on the basis of his interjection when the Minister failed to answer my question. The hypocrisy of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and another Minister in the other place is shown by what the proper answer to the question should have been-that the total English as a second language (ESL) allocation is down by 4.5 per cent this year. In real terms, the total ESL cutback is 11.5 per cent. This year's cutback follows the massive 44 per cent reduction in 1986. So much for what this Government thinks of teaching English to migrants.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 25 November, from Senator Wood:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The necessity for the Government to provide, by way of an inquiry by a Senate committee or otherwise, an explanation of the functions of the proposed satellite monitoring and communications facility at Geraldton, and to give an account of the cost of the facility and reasons for any increase in the estimated cost.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The necessity for the Government to provide, by way of an inquiry by a Senate committee or otherwise, an explanation of the functions of the proposed satellite monitoring and communications facility at Geraldton, and to give an account of the cost of the facility and reasons for any increase in the estimated cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that this matter has to be dealt with by way of an urgency motion. Earlier today there was an attempt to have the whole matter referred to a Senate standing committee for inquiry. That would have been our preferred method of dealing with this question because we realise that the Government will now refuse to give us any information in any way and hence will paint itself into a corner and that this will probably be the last occasion on which we will hear of this matter from the Government. It is important that this matter be addressed quite thoroughly because it is a question, as is the case with all such spy bases, of Australian sovereignty.

SPEECH.PARA: The questions that must be asked are: What is going on at Geraldton? What will the base there do? Who will it spy on and why? What will be done with the information? Who will get the information, and how much will it cost? Is Geraldton an appropriate site anyway? What about the local people of Geraldton who, it appears, will have their land forcibly taken away from them? Those questions should be addressed. We may have to pursue them further in discussions on the appropriations to get what information we can.

The base at Geraldton will spy on satellites over one-third of the globe. The satellites belong to a wide range of friends, allies-and those who are not our allies-and neighbours. The intelligence and communications intercepted through these satellites will not just be military intelligence; it will be military, political and economic. So the Geraldton base will be listening in on the conversations of our allies and friends in all areas of their operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would not be listening to ours, would they?

—I can answer that question by referring to a nice little glossy leaflet which was put out by the Department of Defence and placed as an insert in the local newspaper. An item under the heading `Important fact' states:

SPEECH.PARA: DSD-
that is, the Defence Signals Directorate-
has no role in domestic intelligence-that is to say, its only role is with foreign intelligence.
That was an assurance that we would not be spying on our own people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You misunderstood what he meant by `they'.
—Are you going to tell me that neighbours around Australia are not listening to what we are doing here?

—No. The base that we already have at Pine Gap, as we know, was spying on Greece. We know that Pine Gap has been used for a whole range of spying missions other than its alleged uses. There is no doubt in my mind that the base at Geraldton will be used for those purposes too. The question in my mind is: whose defence needs is that base catering for-our own or those of foreign powers? There is a United Kingdom-United States of America agreement that a whole host of Anglo-Saxon countries which have agreed to share intelligence will be the main beneficiaries of the intelligence gained from these satellites.
—What's wrong with Anglo- Saxons?

—There is nothing wrong with Anglo-Saxons; in recent history it is just that colonialism and imperialism tend to have been practised most successfully by Anglo-Saxons. That fact that we are here is evidence of that. Whose work will the spy base be doing? Why does Australia need to monitor all the satellites operating in a whole third of the globe? Why do we need to get that information and what could we do with it? Senator MacGibbon and other Opposition senators have said that we do not even have the capability to take over a small country within our region-if we wanted to do so-that our forward defence capability is pretty loose and slack, that our whole defence services have wound down and that we cannot project force within the region.
—That's right.

—Senator MacGibbon says, `That's right'. Why do we need so much military intelligence if we cannot do anything about it anyway? Obviously, we are doing the work for the bullies in the region. We will collect the information from our friends and allies and decode it through technology provided for us, in the main by the United States. That raises the other questions: whose technology is it that will be in the base, what will we have to surrender in exchange for this technology, other than money, and what services will we have to provide?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that Australia should be looking towards a defence capability which is defensive and which allows Australians to defend Australia in event of attack, and not towards further involvement in the nuclear war fighting capabilities of the United States. It seems to me that what is happening at Geraldton is the building of a base that will put Australia further into that game-that Australia will collect in its own right the sort of strategic intelligence needed to be part of a nuclear war fighting game and that that information will be provided to the other nuclear super-powers which will inextricably link us ever deeper into the whole game. It is time that Australia adopted independent foreign and defence policies so that our defence and foreign policies would meet Australia's needs.

The question of our friends and neighbours arises here. Given that we will be spying on and collecting information affecting Indonesia, Japan, China, Italy and a whole range of countries, what does that say to them about our motives? If we spy ever more closely on Indonesia, will that not increase the tension between Australia and Indonesia? Surely the whole notion of defence is about security and the whole notion of security is to reduce tension. Surely the opening of the Geraldton base will increase tensions in the region, not just with us as an appendage to the United States, being involved with it in its tension with others in the region, but in our own right as we create further tension. It seems to me that Australia has a responsibility to operate in a new way in the region-a way which encourages co-operation and communication and secures our borders and citizens without threatening our neighbours and without increasing tension in the region.

Why has there been a sudden massive increase in the projected costs of the Geraldton base? The figures that are now being given are far in excess of the original estimates, and suddenly they are secret. The Government stated that it would fully explain the costs of the Geraldton and other bases. But now they are secret. I did not agree with, but I could understand, the United States not wanting Australians to know what was going on at Pine Gap and other bases it has here, but if the base at Geraldton is to be an Australian spy base, doing Australian spying for Australia, Australians ought to know who is being spied on and why, how much it will cost and what the money will be spent on. There is no question of divulging the secrets of a foreign power, be it the United States or whoever; they can have their secrets. But surely we in Australia should know what our spy bases are doing and how much it is costing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do know that.

—We do not know it. The other day the Minister said that it was Government policy that the figures would not be given. We will pursue the matter in the Estimates committee hearings and in debate on the Appropriation Bills to get some more accurate expenditure figures. I want to know why this Government seems to be embarking on a more closed government policy on these matters than its predecessor. We harassed the previous Government to try to get information about bases and other things in this country. But this Government, which at the time supported those efforts, is now using the same tactics of neither confirming nor denying but hiding its figures. We are demanding that the figures relating to, and the purposes of, the base be a matter of straight public record. We want straight answers to straight questions. The debate today, which I am aware is taking up valuable time, is necessary because the Government will not come clean and answer these questions. That is why this is a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we go any further down the track towards another secret base like Pine Gap which will provoke even more contention, agitation, demonstration and all the rest of it in the community, let us have an open and clean debate on just what is going on at Geraldton. Even the local residents cannot get clear answers on to what is happening at Geraldton. The Department of Administrative Services has offered them a price significantly below the current valuation of their property. It has said that it is now looking at the compulsory acquisition process, `although negotiations will continue'. Even the local residents-I am pleased to see that Wilson Tuckey has taken up their cause-are being bullied. They have not been offered adequate compensation and are not being told the truth.

The buffer zone around the proposed base will be inaccessible to farmers. There is talk about a lease-back arrangement for farmers in the area. The buffer zone will be under licence on a monthly payment basis, with 48 hours notice given to farmers to remove all stock. Senator McGauran is not here to ask, `What about the farmers?' so I will ask that question for him. Can a farmer remove all his stock within 48 hours, without an alternative place to put it? What about the locals of Geraldton? Will they get justice from this Government, or will this Government bully them? What about the safety of the Geraldton site? A local resident is reported in a newspaper article as follows:
`I wish to point out the stupidity of choosing this site as it is on a severe earthquake fault,' . . . `You would need to be blind not to see the evidence of past quakes there'.
Mrs Martin said she had been living on the farm when the Cadoux earthquake occurred. That quake happened on June 2 1979 and measured 6.2 on the richter scale.
It is not just a question of Australian sovereignty and the threatening of our neighbours but also a question of bullying the locals and of inadequate preparation of the proposal for this site.

I conclude by reiterating the questions that we want answered. What is the base at Geraldton going to do? It is capable of doing a great deal of spying-economic, political and military. What sort of information will it concentrate on? To whom will this information go, and for what purpose? For whose strategic interest will all this information be collected, and at what cost? Are Australians to pay the cost of building and maintaining the base, together with the cost of collecting the information and then passing it on to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Pentagon and anyone else in the Anglo-Saxon club? Is it a question of Australia paying for and doing someone else's dirty work? Why the secrecy, and why the bullying of the locals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Minister for Home Affairs) (3.28)-The Australian defence satellite communications station (ADSCS) to be built at Geraldton is one of the most important elements in this Government's program to make Australia self-reliant in its own defence. That program has received the almost universal acclaim of the Australian community. Disagreements, when they have come from, say, the Left, including the sort of opinion espoused by Senator Wood and his supporters, have been to the effect that our self-reliant posture does not go far enough. The honourable senator stressed that again today. There are people who argue that we ought to declare ourselves completely non-aligned and deprive ourselves of any assistance from other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: What these people need to understand is how important good intelligence is to the maintenance of a self-reliant defence posture and of security in our region. They also need to understand that the ADSCS at Geraldton will be the most significant intelligence project ever undertaken in this country and that the sort of inquiry they propose would go a long way toward rendering taxpayers' investment at Geraldton worthless, Australia less secure and the region more unstable. The simple and naive view of Senator Wood and his companions is that intelligence is bad and dangerous. They are wrong. It is ignorance which is dangerous because ignorance leads to mistaken fears.

Let me give a concrete example from recent history. Much of the blame for the nuclear arms race of the last 25 years can be laid at the door of inadequate United States intelligence about Soviet weapons developments in the early 1960s. The United States came to believe that the Soviet Union was engaged in massive weapons developments which it feared would overwhelm its own forces. In fact, it was quite wrong. It systematically overestimated Soviet strengths because its information about actual Soviet weapons developments was sketchy. Without hard information, US officials had to do a lot of guessing, and they inevitably assumed the worst. The result was a growing fear of a missile gap which would leave the United States vulnerable to a Soviet first strike. The result of that wrong assessment of a Soviet build-up was a very real US buildup. The US started a massive weapons program to meet the Soviet threat that did not exist. In response to that US build-up, the Soviets began a massive buildup of their own-starting an arms race which is only now showing signs of coming under some control.

This history lesson needs to be considered very carefully by Senator Wood and his supporters. I do not know whether Senator Wood reads Marx, but he has probably heard that those who do not study history are condemned to repeat the mistakes of the past. Let me give an example of how this tragic piece of history could be repeated in our own case, were we to follow Senator Wood's proposal to nobble our own intelligence capabilities. Senator Wood may be aware, if he has taken enough interest in Australia's defence to read the Government White Paper on the subject, that our defence posture is based on the concept of warning. It is important that he understands that. Put simply, Australia's defence forces are designed to be able to meet any threat that could emerge at relatively short notice. We do not maintain the massive forces that would be needed to defend Australia against an all-out invasion, because we know that there are no forces around that are large enough to pose that threat at the moment. It is absolutely fundamental to that strategy that we must be confident in our ability to detect any changes to the forces in our region, and beyond, that could threaten us, and we need to be able to detect them early enough to respond effectively.

That is the reason why we place the highest priority on the most effective intelligence possible. If we were not confident that we could detect strategic changes that might threaten us before those threats actually emerge, Australia would have to maintain massively larger armed forces than it does. That would be a tragedy in two ways. Firstly, it would be an enormous cost to the nation. At the minimum, we would need to double our defence spending to $15 billion per year. That would be a disaster for our economy, and could not help but undermine the social goals of this Government. But that would be the lesser of the two evils which would flow from the defence buildup which Senator Wood appears to regard as preferable to effective intelligence.

I ask Senator Wood to consider how the countries of the region would respond to a sudden doubling of defence spending by Australia. The answer is painfully obvious: they would quite naturally begin to worry about what we were up to. Their response would very likely be to start building up their own defences. We, in turn, in ignorance and fear, would redouble our own efforts, and so on. I think the final outcome can be imagined-and I do not imagine it is the outcome that Senator Wood really wants. I hope this helps Senator Wood to understand why we regard good intelligence as essential to our self-reliant defence posture, and fundamental to regional stability.

I draw the Senate's attention to a similar intellectual difficulty which Senator Wood and his fellows have in relation to the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. They continue to oppose the operations of those facilities in the face of all the evidence-not all of which comes from the Government, I might say-that those facilities make an absolutely fundamental contribution to the maintenance of deterrence, and to the hopes of arms control. Senator Wood does not like intelligence, but he cannot avoid the vital contribution that good intelligence makes to keeping the peace.

But let us get back to the base at Geraldton, which is not a joint facility. It will be a wholly Australian owned, operated and managed facility. Senator Wood believes that we are not telling him as much as he would like to know about the station and its functions-too true. He might like to note, though, that this Government has done much more than any of its predecessors to open up the operations of the Australian intelligence community, including the joint facilities, to public knowledge. In doing so, we have been guided by two principles. The first is that we should release as much information as possible. The second is that we should not release information which would reduce the effectiveness of these operations. Following these principles, we have released as much as we can.

In relation to the joint facilities, for example, we have massively increased the amount of information on the public record, in the Prime Minister's statement on 6 June 1984, in the White Paper this year and elsewhere. In relation to Geraldton, we have from the first given the maximum information about the facility. For example, we have identified the ADSCS as a facility of the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD). This is the first time we have identified any DSD facility. We have given a description of the functions of the facility which is accurate, and as complete as can reasonably be given without risking the effectiveness with which it can perform those functions. I might point out that a lot of the points raised in Senator Wood's speech regarding the functions of the Geraldton facility are nothing more than arrant speculation. Although it seems obvious, the link between secrecy and effectiveness in the intelligence business seems to have escaped Senator Wood's attention, so I suppose it is worth going over it one more time.

The fact is that any substantial information about an intelligence operation could be used to help frustrate it. How such information could be used in that way may be a mystery to Senator wood and others, but I doubt that he would claim any great expertise in this area. To the experts, small snippets of information carefully assembled can yield a lot of data, and that data can be used to frustrate our intelligence efforts. We are spending large amounts of taxpayers' money on intelligence activities and we do not consider it useful to risk wasting it. We have told as much as we can about Geraldton because we believe it is important that Australians understand that our defence posture is underpinned by adequate and effective intelligence capabilities. To say more would simply undermine the effectiveness of the facility and the security of this country.

Senator Wood in his motion also raises the issue of the cost of the facility, which he believes has increased. I am unaware of the origin of that belief, unless it is Senator Vallentine's discussions with the farmers or officers of the Department who did not know the actual cost. Perhaps he is just reflecting the edifice of speculation on the same subject presented by Senator Vallentine yesterday. At any rate, in our view they are both wrong. No cost for the facility has been published but I can assure them that the estimated cost of the project has not increased-that is the one assurance that I am willing to give. I therefore propose that Senator Wood's motion be defeated, on the grounds that the inquiry called for is unnecessary and dangerous. It is unnecessary because the Government has already given all the information it responsibly can about the project. It is dangerous because to give any more information would undermine the effectiveness of the station, the security of Australia, and the stability of the region.

Going to the question of the urgency of this matter, the main urgency to discuss it today is because we are on radio, so I will not spend any more time on that. When will, and when can senators expect to know exactly what happens at Geraldton? It is when their party wins 75 seats in the House of Representatives, and they will be informed as the incoming government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a cynical statement.

—It is not a cynical statement. That is the reality. That is our position. It is the one we had before the election and the one that we have afterwards. It is a consistent position. Just because it does not agree with Senator Vallentine's position, she calls it cynical.
—You have not supplied enough information.

—Senator Vallentine says that I have not supplied enough information. Senator Wood comes in and says that we are spying on Greece. He has no authority for that and has put forward no evidence. I suggest that the evidence came from a third-rate journalist in a second-rate rag called the National Times, which will repeat any piece of flip information about security services. That is the bible of Senator Sanders because it appeals to the naivety in certain people. I would not be surprised if the first thing that Senator Sanders does every day when he gets up is read his stars. He is just the sort of naive type to believe in astrology. I believe that he is irredeemably lost to rational debate or anything else. I do not believe that about Senator Wood and I will hold judgment on Senator Vallentine.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders is a lost cause. Maybe, deep in Senator Sanders's childhood, he read too much Enid Blyton. Maybe he should have been brought up on the Miller's Guide, like myself. He seems also to have a metaphysical block. Senator Sanders is a blockhead, but these people have a metaphysical block when it comes to the Soviet Union. It is not there, it does not exist, in their minds. I have hardly ever heard them refer to an arms build-up in the Soviet Union, the invasion of Afghanistan or anything else-it does not exist. It is not that they are not sincere on the subject. If their attention is drawn to those issues they will respond in a humanitarian and rational way, but they never initiate those issues in this chamber. We never hear from them about these issues. I am appalled by the fact. I never grew up to be either particularly pro- or anti-American; one does not, in the Australian Labor Party.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true. The traditions of the Australian Labor Party are neither pro- nor anti-American. We have developed our defence and foreign affairs policy in relation to where we see the basic interests of Australia resting. At the moment, in terms of world social systems, as a preferable choice we will take the Americans every time. But this sort of absence always represents criticism of Australia, of Australia's defence posture and intelligence gathering. We never hear criticism of the KGB. It is as though it does not exist. I am reminded of what happened in the middle of the Profumo affair when Prime Minister Macmillan marched into the House of Commons and said, `Operating in this country we have the finest secret service in the world', to which a Labour backbencher said, `Yes, the KGB'.

SPEECH.PARA: We must know early where the trouble spots in our region are. It can be done only by gathering intelligence. It will not occur through a leak in the National Times that there is a build-up in a neighbouring country. The more we expose the methods of gathering that intelligence, the more useless it is.

In conclusion, we have been charged with three charges. We have been charged with not giving a full account, a detailed account, of what this facility at Geraldton will do. That is correct. Secondly, we will not give a total cost or a breakdown of costs on that facility. That is correct. That is Government policy; it will remain Government policy while we are on this side of the House and, I suspect, even when we are on that other side of the House, the incoming Government will take the same attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had an example of a man having absolutely nothing to say. I find that when people have nothing to say they indulge in personal abuse. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) had no facts. He launched into a massive cover-up based, at first, on anecdotes-and rather spurious historical anecdotes they were. He then launched into personal abuse of anyone who questions-just questions-the base and what it might do. For this questioning we were branded communists and, by implication, traitors. It was said that we never really talked about the Soviet Union-that we talked only about what the United States might do. I point out that the Soviet Union does not maintain a base such as Pine Gap in Australia. The Americans do. The Soviet Union does not. If the Soviet Union did, we would be just as concerned about the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister accused us of being ignorant. Of course we are ignorant; we have had no information from this Government about the functions of this base or what it is to cost. Even in loose and rough terms we have nothing. The Minister's speech sounded very much like speeches made by apologists for the Fraser Government when it was in office. What happened to this Labor Party Government on the way to the election, I wonder? It has become a Laborial government, the Hawke conservative government. It sounds very much like the Fraser Government. It is not our supposedly open Labor Party.

The Minister then brought up the hoary old chestnut of verification. I guess, by implication, the Geraldton base is to be used in some way for verification. Certainly, the Minister mentioned that Pine Gap is used for verification. Pine Gap certainly was not set up for verification, because it was set up long before the treaties which it now has a minor role in verifying were even known.

Why are we having an independent satellite communication station? Certainly, I am all in favour of independence, but why do we have to pay $300m for this information gathering station? If it must be independent and if we are paying this money, this must be the Government admitting that Pine Gap is not a joint facility. This must be an admission by the Government that the Pine Gap information is solely US information and that Pine Gap is solely a US base. If this information were being shared with us, we simply would not need to have our own facility. If Pine Gap were a joint facility and we had full access to all information at Pine Gap, there would be absolutely no need for an independent facility at Geraldton. Perhaps we are not getting our full value from Pine Gap. I say-not only `perhaps' but, in fact, absolutely-that we are not getting the full information from Pine Gap. We are being denied information. Members of the Australian defence community know that this is the case. They know that this is not a joint facility and that is one of the reasons why they may be building this base. There may be another reason and I will come to that in a while.

What does the Geraldton base do? I suppose it is logical to assume that it will operate, although we have no firm information on this, in a manner similar to Pine Gap. We have had a lot of talk about Pine Gap in this chamber. However, I think it is useful to go back over what Pine Gap is so that we can find out, since the Government will not tell us, what Geraldton might do. Okay, what does Pine Gap do? Pine Gap facility, which became operational in 1969, of course, is located 19 kilometres south-west of Alice Springs. The business end of the facility consists of seven large radomes and an enormous computer complex, currently being expanded. This computer complex is very necessary to decode all the signals that come in. Although Pine Gap is formally administered by the US National Reconnaissance Office, it is operationally controlled by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

Pine Gap was originally established as part of the Rhyolite project, which was easily the most sophisticated and comprehensive global surveillance system ever conceived. Basically, Rhyolite comprises three master satellites at geostationary altitude above the earth-which is about 36,000 kilometres-and positioned about 120 degrees apart. In this configuration the satellites provide for world-wide surveillance and monitoring of all-I repeat, all-telephonic and radio microwave communications, together with radar emissions, telemetry signals and a vast range of other radio emanations in every country on earth. In other words, the three master satellites act like giant vacuum cleaners, sucking up a wide spectrum of communications and radio signals and returning the raw data to ground stations at Pine Gap, Redondo Beach, California, and CIA headquarters at Langley, Virginia. One of the worries that we have about Pine Gap is the definition of what is called--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MacGibbon

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to apply standing order 419, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall digress from the subject-matter of any Question under discussion.

The necessity of the Government to provide, by way of an inquiry by a Senate committee or otherwise, an explanation of the functions of the proposed satellite monitoring and communications facility at Geraldton, and to give an account of the cost of the facility and reasons for any increase in the estimated cost.
I submit that the detailed assured functions of Pine Gap are quite irrelevant to the way this debate has run.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Sanders is developing his argument by arguing that the new base is unnecessary, or could be unnecessary, because of the existence of Pine Gap. I think that is an argument relevant to the question being asked. I call Senator Sanders.
—Mr Deputy President--
—It must be a different point of order, Senator MacGibbon.

—Yes, Mr Deputy President. I suggest, with the greatest respect, that your decision is based on a false assumption because the assumption is that Pine Gap is the same facility as the proposed defence signals intercept facility at Geraldton. There is no signals intercept facility at Pine Gap, nor will there be in the future. There is no parallel between Pine Gap and the proposed facility at Geraldton.

—Order! I have ruled on the point of order. Senator MacGibbon's subsequent submission disputes my ruling. I am not in a position to decide what the functions of Pine Gap are. Senator Sanders is entitled to make such speculations if he likes, if it helps his argument.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I think it is quite relevant to discuss Pine Gap in this issue because its functions are typical of those of a satellite communications station and I think it is necessary, in fact, to find out what these stations do. The problem with Pine Gap, and it is one reason we are concerned about it, is that its capacity for determining signals from all around the Soviet Union, in particular, creates an opportunity for a first strike capability for the United States. If the Soviet facilities, such as microwave links and other communications systems, go off the air, it is a possible time to launch a first strike and, as such, it is destabilising.

SPEECH.PARA: Another very interesting function of Pine Gap, and something that Geraldton may or may not be involved in-we do not know because the Government will not tell us, but it very well could be-is a new development in the Aquacade satellite program. There are three Aquacade satellites, and they have only recently been placed in orbit. Three types of satellites-the Rhyolite, the Argus and the Aquacade-have allowed the United States to monitor, collect and analyse all civil and military communications emanating from anywhere on earth. But the systems do a lot more than that. The three master satellites are used for covert communications between US military and intelligence personnel around the world. This is the so-called Pyramider project and its existence was first revealed during the trial of Christopher Boyce, the convicted US spy, in April 1977. At Boyce's trial, Leslie Dirks, the Deputy Director of Science and Technology at the CIA, stated that the Pyramider project involved creating a system which would provide covert communications links between US intelligence agents in both open and denied areas of the world; communications with a global network of emplaced sensors which include a variety of devices collecting data remotely; and back-up communications to overseas installations in the event of regular channels of communication being disrupted. The prime objective of the Pyramider project was, according to Dirks, to ensure `maximum undetectability', and the essence of the system was to conceal the presence of secret operations.

This is the sort of function, I suppose, that Geraldton could be involved in. I ask the Minister and his Government whether it is intended either, firstly, to set up such a program at Geraldton with our own spies or, secondly, to work with the United States program. This brings up some major questions. How do we get this intelligence in the first place? Whose satellites are we going to use? Are we going to launch our own, or are we going to tap into other satellites? If we tap into other satellites, are we going to get information from, for instance, the Americans on how to do it when they are transmitting or how to key their satellites? Do we have any information on this? The Minister is looking bored because he obviously has no information. Are we going to launch satellites? Does part of this include the launching of our own satellites? We do not know. One thing that worries me is that this may not, in fact, be an independent facility at all. This may be the first stage of the withdrawal of Pine Gap.

Pine Gap is one of the two most vulnerable links, in a public relations sense, in the whole US system in Australia-the other being North West Cape. North West Cape is vulnerable because of the fact that its purest function, its only function, is communication with warships. It has no verification function whatsoever. Pine Gap is vulnerable because it is a spy base. It is run by the CIA. It would make infinitely good sense for the United States to eliminate this controversy by eliminating Pine Gap and letting the Australian Government take over all the functions of Pine Gap and take over all the functions at the new base at Geraldton, thus getting the Americans off the propaganda hook. They will not have the bad Press any more. Let the Australians do it. Let it be a totally Australian facility and not a joint facility. That makes infinitely good sense to the Americans and if it makes good sense to the Americans, it probably makes good sense to the Hawke conservative Government because we know that the Hawke Government is very supportive of the Americans. No matter what they do to our farmers in the wheat trade or in regard to any other type of export, the Hawke Government will support the Americans. I submit that the reason that the Minister is not telling us about Geraldton is that it is not going to be an Australian base at all; it will be run for the Americans by the Australians. I think that is a terrible thing. The Minister is looking even more bored; he is looking at the ceiling and he is rolling his eyes. He obviously would like to make us believe that there is absolutely no substance to this, but I do not think he is going to carry out that role successfully.

I would just like to close with some observations about what happened when Pine Gap first came on the scene. The Australian Government first agreed to the establishment of Pine Gap in 1966. At the time it seems our leaders had no idea of the precise purpose of the installation. Does that sound familiar? In fact, three of Australia's recent Prime Ministers have gone on record as saying they were ignorant of the major aspects of Pine Gap. In December 1978 John Gorton admitted:
I don't even know what Pine Gap is all about. I didn't then . . . I could have asked but it didn't arise. I didn't ask about it.
In May 1977, talking about Pine Gap and Nurrungar, Sir William McMahon said:
I have increasing doubts that the Australian Government knows the entire truth.

Gough Whitlam-I do not know whether or not Senator Robert Ray likes Gough Whitlam; I thought he was a wonderfully good Prime Minister and he is actually the reason I came to Australia-has revealed on a number of occasions that he was never told certain critical aspects relating to Pine Gap. For example, no one saw fit to tell him that the first officer in charge of the base was a CIA employee or that Pine Gap was a CIA facility. Over and over again these leaders said they did not know what was going on. Our government does not know what is going on at Geraldton. Are we entering yet another agreement with our eyes shut?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have learned one thing today; that is, that a further legacy of the Whitlam regime is Senator Sanders. I suggest it is a matter of great regret, and I doubt whether even former Prime Minister Whitlam would wish to claim that doubtful privilege. Senator Sanders's contribution was indeed disappointing and I think in some ways even offensive to Senator Wood, who raised this matter. He very seriously and reasonably sought further information from this Government on the various facilities, including their cost. I say it is reasonable to seek that information; it is not always in the best interests of the nation that the Government should give it. That is one frustration of matters that do fall within high security classification. It is a frustration that from time to time some of us on this side of the House experience when we would wish further information. But unfortunately it is a fact of life that when matters have a high security classification, as has this particular installation, the wide giving of information on detailed functions could clearly, in some circumstances, not be in the best interests of the nation. That is something that we on this side of the House recognise.

SPEECH.PARA: I am somewhat surprised that Senator Wood has taken this position in his speech which, on the face of it, would appear to indicate opposition to this facility. I would have thought that it was the type of non-violent contribution to Australia's defence that the senator for nuclear disarmament would be applauding. I would have thought that a senator for nuclear disarmament would prefer us to be spending more on an intelligence capacity, a capacity to predict what might happen in the future and, therefore, to take steps-they may be diplomatic steps or other steps-other than purely defence steps to move in this country's best interests. I am somewhat surprised about Senator Wood's position on this matter, when the facility would give us greater independence in this capacity. Contrary to what Senator Wood said, it would in some ways give us greater independence from what he refers to as the nuclear war fighting game because, as he is well aware, this intelligence facility is to be solely operated by Australian personnel and the information gained from it will be solely in Australian government hands. I would have thought that, on the face of it, factors in the installation of this facility would appeal to a senator from the Nuclear Disarmament Party. I am somewhat surprised, therefore, that he has taken the position he has.

The Opposition does not see this matter as urgent. We do not at this time think it is appropriate for the matter to be referred to a Senate committee. Therefore we will vote against the motion. I say that, applying the same rule to us as I do to the nuclear disarmament people, it is quite legitimate in the future to seek further information on the functions of this facility and the costs involved. We will do that in the future through the proper avenues. We anticipate that in due course the leadership of the Opposition, the alternative government, will be briefed in the same way as it is briefed on the joint intelligence facilities. If there are matters that, after we have pursued all the proper courses, we find are unsatisfactory in our opinion we have recourse to the options of this parliamentary process.

We approach these matters from a different point of view. We do not presume that a facility gaining defence intelligence information for this nation has something sinister about it or that something is being hidden from us for purely political purposes. We are prepared, at the moment, to take such a facility on face value. On the other hand, we are entitled to factual information. We will be determining a detailed policy on this matter in the same way as we determine detailed policy on all defence aspects, and in due course we will make that policy public. I must say that it is our impression that more information is available than Senator Wood seems to think. Certainly, I was aware, as the Government has stated in this debate, that the information provided about the purpose of this facility and the role of the Defence Signals Directorate in relation to it is greater than is normally given in such circumstances. I think that is a trend in the right direction, provided the Government does not go beyond its defence and intelligence responsibilities.

On the information that is available, our immediate reaction is that we think the facility will be a worthwhile contribution to Australia's defence capacities. Basically we agree with what appears in the Defence White Paper, upon which the announcement of this facility was based. I refer to chapter 4, paragraphs 2, 3, 4 and 5, in which it is said:
A high level of capability in strategic intelligence is fundamental.
That is something we agree with. It says:
This allows us to review developments in the defence capabilities and political positions of other countries and to monitor them for changes that could affect our security.
That seems obvious to us and is something that is in our best interests. It says:
Our intelligence priorities focus on those potential changes that affect us directly.

We agree with that; it is the major distinction between this facility and Pine Gap-and a distinction that perhaps Senator MacGibbon, who has some expertise in this field, touched upon when he intervened some time ago. We in this country do not have the capacity at the moment to monitor satellite communications within our region. We have a responsibility in that area not only to ourselves but also to our friends and allies in the wider Western alliance. This facility would give us the capacity to do so whereas, as we know, Pine Gap and the other major joint facilities have a much wider international strategic role. This report goes on to say-and we agree:
We must also, however, be able to assess developments beyond our region of primary strategic interest.
This facility, an independent facility in Australia's hands, would enable us to do that. The report goes on to say:
The Government plans to enhance our independent intelligence capabilities by establishing a large satellite communications station in Western Australia.
That facility has now been announced and is the subject of this debate. It says:
This will contribute to Australia's security in our area of strategic interest. The station will be totally Australian owned and will be manned and operated by the Defence Signals Directorate.

As I have indicated, on the face of that document we agree with what is stated therein. Similarly, we agree with that part of the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities which deals with the same matter. Under the chapter headed `Intelligence and Surveillance', on page 60, Mr Dibb says:
Our national intelligence assets and analytical effort should be primarily oriented to this region and we should seek a high level of intelligence self-reliance within this area.

That is something with which we agree. I stress that it is only part of our capacity to gain this intelligence information. It has to be added to the various early warning capacities we have, with the over the horizon radar being developed, and so on. Nevertheless, it seems to us that on the face of the public information we have at the moment, which we think is reasonable information, the case is well made out.

I have tried very briefly to draw a distinction between a capacity such as this and that of joint facilities such as Pine Gap, which are really part of a different league in this field-the big league. Nevertheless, we on this side of the chamber support our contribution to facilitating the gathering of information on the world scene and, in part, the gathering of information in the nuclear arms race which we believe has a deterrent capacity. We strongly support the Western alliance. We do not hedge from that position. We strongly support our contribution, which we think is rather moderate, in providing facilities in a joint approach through those major bases in Australia.

This facility has a much more limited capacity. It will involve a contribution we can make to our own defence at times when we might be threatened by a contingency that is of lesser concern to the super-powers. It might just be that the time will come when the concentration of the United States is on matters that concern super-powers and not on regional matters of concern to us. Therefore, to have our own capacity to gather information that we believe is of importance to the security of this country, to be able to process that information through our experts and to analyse and use it in an independent way that we believe is in the best interests of this country, we think is a valuable asset. I do not want to go through the details of the base, which we have heard from others. Geraldton, in many ways it seems, is particularly well placed. If it is possible from Geraldton to monitor signals travelling to and fro on approximately one-third of the world's surface, that in itself seems to be some evidence that it is well placed.

It is public knowledge that our Defence Signals Directorate is capable and well able to operate a base such as this, both in the tasks of interception and the decrypting of information that we get from it. Other speakers have touched upon what is done with the information and who we might provide with it. Even when one negotiates with friends it is better to be able to give something if one wants to be assured of what one gets in return. I have no doubt that information that we gain from this facility from time to time we will be able to provide to our friends and allies in a positive effort in our mutual best interests to achieve greater security of this region and the world. On the face of the information that we have at the moment, which we think is reasonable in the circumstances, there is a good argument for a facility such as this.

The way in which the Government has handled this matter at the grass-roots level in relation to property acquisition has been ham-fisted. That is a matter of great regret. It should have thought it was important to get the local people on side with a project such as this in the national interest. Rather there has been the attempted acquisition of part of a farm which in effect would put people out of business, take away their livelihood and their life's work. I also regret that the Government has not told the local people what will happen in relation to local air restrictions and whether the operation of their farms, petrol engines and aerial spraying will affect the capacity of these signals. The local people need to be reassured about matters of basic operations of their properties so that they can have confidence in what is happening around them. On the face of the matter, as I have indicated, we certainly do not see urgency for this motion at this time and we certainly do not see that it is in the national interest at the moment for a Senate inquiry to seek further information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that is at stake here today--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, are you seeking leave to make a personal explanation?
—No, I will do that later if I may. I wish to enter into the debate.
—You are breaking a commitment.
—I know an arrangement was made that there would be one speaker a side.
—A firm arrangement, as usual, was broken.

—I do not belong to a side. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has given a completely inadequate speech on this subject and therefore I feel absolutely compelled to speak, if only for a few moments.
—Proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. There are a couple of points that have not been brought out in this debate this afternoon that I think require comment at this stage. It is only because of the Minister's totally inadequate speech that I feel compelled--
—You had 10 minutes this morning.

—I had eight minutes this morning and then the debate was cut off. I am compelled now to reiterate some of the points that have not been made in this debate this afternoon. What is at issue here is the taxpayers' right to know what the Government is spending their money on. The Government has not answered the basic question of the huge discrepancy in the amount that was first bandied about of $20m to $25m, which it has not denied. At the time when the Age and the Australian Financial Review cited that amount of money, it did not deny that estimate. It is my assumption that both those newspapers got that figure from a reliable source; in other words, an unofficial statement from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). The Government has not denied that and now we have the figure of $300m. The Government is refusing to give any explanation of that huge increase in costs, an astronomical increase in costs. So the Government has not told us about that, it has not told us about the function, nor has it given us any adequate explanation of the methodology of the land acquisition. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: I had just about finished my remarks. The main point I wanted to raise was the Government's lack of answers on the method of land acquisition, as well as the astronomical increase in costs. The Government, I believe, has been very irresponsible in its arrogant refusal to answer questions from concerned citizens. This is not the last that the Government will be hearing from the people of the Geraldton region or from Australian taxpayers in general. It is displaying a clear denial of the notion of government responsibility. I think that the Government ought to be responsible and ought to be held accountable for the decisions it is making on behalf of Australian taxpayers. Therefore, I commend this matter of urgency to all honourable senators.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Wood's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with Senator Short's motion of 5 November 1987, I now present to the Senate draft regulations which have been prepared for the consideration of His Excellency the Governor-General after the enactment of the Migration Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I thank Senator Reynolds for tabling the draft regulations, following the request by the Opposition in regard to the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 that these key regulations, which are a fundamental part of the Bill that is being debated by the Senate, were needed in order for the Senate adequately to consider the Bill. I thank Senator Reynolds for giving me a little notice of the regulations, but they are detailed and in the time available, obviously, I have not had a chance to consider them in any detail. TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, in his speech in the chamber a short while ago when he claimed that my colleagues and I seem to have a personal block about the Soviet Union, that we never criticise the Soviet Union. I speak only on my own behalf: that is absolutely not true. I have often in this place questioned and criticised the actions of the Soviet Union, specifically in relation to the build-up of its naval forces in the Pacific, its presence in Afghanistan, its presence at Cam Ranh Bay and on human rights issues. I would be happy to provide Senator Ray with a list of the statements that I have made in this place and of Press statements that I have released to the media since I have been a senator-not all of which have been taken up, I might add. It is absolutely false to suggest that I have a mental block about the Soviet Union as a threat to world peace. Of course, I acknowledge that fact and I have often said in this place that I am opposed to nuclear weapons of all powers, no matter which political side of the fence they are on. I am opposed to nuclear weapons; I am not opposed to one super-power any more than the other in this regard. I really resent the fact that I have been accused of having a mental block about the Soviet Union.
—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. I prefaced my remarks by saying that I have never heard Senator Vallentine--

On 7 October 1987 the Senate asked the Committee to examine a proposed amendment to section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act that was contained in the current Statute Law Bill. The amendment was designed to allow a regulation to come into effect at a specified time of the day or on the commencement of a specified Act. In the post-Australia Card atmosphere then prevailing, concern was expressed that such a provision, appearing in a Statute Law Bill, affecting the time and date of commencement of regulations could have been intended to allow controversial regulations to bypass the disallowance powers of Parliament. The Committee has examined the proposed amendment and the context in which it arose and we are satisfied that the proposals did not in any way arise in the context of consideration of Australia Card regulations. The Committee is also satisfied that the proposed amendment as such would not facilitate the avoidance of disallowance powers. However, in the course of its inquiries the Committee has realised that, regardless of these new amendments, the disallowance procedures of the Senate can already be bypassed by a procedure we have called the repeal and re-enactment device. This would allow a delegated lawmaker, quite lawfully, to frustrate the Senate's wish to disallow regulations by quickly repealing them and remaking them before disallowance could occur. Although there are, obviously, practical difficulties attached to this, this process could go on indefinitely.

As a result of the Committee's recommendations the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has agreed to amend the Acts Interpretation Act to remove this loophole which could otherwise defeat the Senate's capacity to oversee subordinate laws made under parliamentary authority. The Committee will be pressing for the amendment to be made as soon as reasonably practicable. It will require careful drafting. I might add that the repeal and re-enactment loophole has not, to our knowledge, ever been exploited although it was known about as early as 1970, when Senator Lionel Murphy strongly criticised it as a possible means of defeating the Senate's supervisory role. The Committee takes some satisfaction in correcting this matter some 17 years after it was first raised in the Senate. The mills of the Regulation and Ordinance Committee grind slowly but exceeding small.

The Committee has also persuaded the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, to make a further slight amendment to his proposed amendment in the Statute Law Bill to ensure that the existing rule in the Acts Interpretation Act against retrospectivity is not inadvertently weakened as it might otherwise have been by the proposed amendment to section 48. Senator Tate has agreed to do this and the amendments have been circulated. The Committee thanks both Ministers for the assistance they have given us and for their readiness to meet the Committee's concerns to protect the disallowance mechanism of this Senate.

Finally, I would like to thank the members of the Committee for the way in which they handled this matter. Impinging as it did on the Australia Card issue and the role of the Senate, it could have been a difficult inquiry. The bipartisanship of the Committee members and their refusal to make political capital out of the Committee's work have been the hallmarks of the Committee for the past 50 years. These features were no less evident in this special inquiry than they are in our normal scrutiny activities.

When I say that it is of fundamental importance to the Parliament, I think it has been claimed with justice that it is, of course, with the exception of the Constitution itself, perhaps the most important statute on the statute books of the Commonwealth. It is so important of course because fundamentally it governs the relationship between the Parliament on the one hand and the Executive Government, that is Ministers, on the other hand. While we naturally in this chamber and, indeed, in another place contest between one side and the other for actions on the part of Executive Government, nevertheless there are matters in which both sides of this chamber not only should join but also, I am happy to say, very often do join in a defence of the rights of the people, as distinct from the powers of Executive Government and Ministers. I think those points have been cogently made this afternoon or, touched upon at least, by Senator Harradine. I take this opportunity of saying that I agree very much with what he had to say.

I would simply like to conclude by saying, as others have done, that I too would like to join in congratulating the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) who, I am glad to see, is just entering the chamber and his colleague in the other place, the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, for the proper consideration they have given to the views of the Committee in these important questions and the extent to which they have, again I think quite properly, dealt with them-although, I am afraid bitter experience suggests that Ministers are not always so compliant to the views put to them by others. In this case I am very glad to say that the two Ministers concerned have been entirely proper in their attitude towards the suggestions made to them by Senator Collins in his capacity as Chairman of that Committee.

Finally, I would like to make a personal tribute to Senator Collins as Chairman of the Committee for his devoted work. I think it can quite properly be described as such, given the extent to which this Committee has been meeting at all hours of the day and night, not only on this subject, I should add. It is proper to put down a tribute to the personal contribution Senator Collins has made to this outcome. I take great pleasure in doing so. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Senator Crowley, I tabled further additional information received by Estimates Committee C.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill, which is based on the Bill of the same name which was passed by the House of Representatives during the autumn sittings, has been revised and extended in consultation with major banks. I welcome the banks' co-operation in the preparation of this legislation and their commitment to assisting law enforcement agencies in the fight against crime.

The Bill represents one of the most significant initiatives to counter the underground cash economy, tax evasion and money laundering. It is notorious that the underground cash economy provides great scope for tax evasion both domestically and internationally. It is clear that traditional investigative techniques have been ineffective in identifying financiers of major crime, because of the ease with which such persons are able to distance themselves from the actual criminal conduct. However, experience both in Australia and overseas has shown that criminal financiers associate more closely with the profits of crime. That experience also shows that cash is an important part of financing criminal activity.

Recent investigations have confirmed that numerous accounts have continued to be opened in false names and millions of dollars in cash have been laundered through those accounts. The financial institutions have agreed to co-operate with law enforcement bodies and to implement new procedures in an endeavour to prevent the abuse of their services by criminals. Financial institutions have sought an avenue for reporting suspect transactions, of any kind, to law enforcement agencies. This Bill provides that avenue. The Bill also creates an offence of opening or operating an account in a false name.

This Bill will give law enforcement agencies the ability to monitor the movement of large amounts of cash and thus to identify tax evaders and the recipients of proceeds of crime. The legislation is consistent with calls by a number of royal commissions and other inquiries in recent years for stronger measures to deal with the widespread abuse of the facilities of financial institutions in relation to tax fraud and other criminal activities. The Bill implements a scheme for the reporting of certain large currency transactions conducted through various institutions and certain transfers of currency into and out of Australia.

The Bill provides comprehensive measures for the control of the cash economy and minimisation of tax evasion. These include the requirement that certain types of transactions be reported to the Cash Transactions Reports Agency. The reportable transactions include large-scale cash transactions, any suspect transactions, the export of foreign currency and the import of foreign and Australian currency over a prescribed level. These reports will be supplemented by the verification of the identity of account holders whose accounts exceed a prescribed limit.

Honourable senators will note that this limited verification requirement is not as extensive as the provisions of the earlier Bill which was passed by the House of Representatives in the last Parliament. The Government has accepted the arguments of the financial institutions that the verification of all accounts would be too great a burden. The Government also recognised that the banks are not able to verify existing accounts despite the best intentions behind their voluntary code for opening accounts. Accordingly, this Bill places the onus of verification on the customer. However, many customers, particularly infants and the elderly, would be greatly inconvenienced if the verification required applied to their small accounts and transactions. Therefore, such small accounts have been exempted by setting a prescribed transaction, deposit limit.

The reporting and verification will be of great value in following the money trail for proceeds of all criminal activities, including tax evasion, and in detecting financiers of criminal activity such as drug trafficking. The thrust of the scheme is broadly similar to the successful scheme in operation in the United States.

The Attorney-General's visit earlier this year to the United States confirmed that the ability to monitor the movements of large amounts of cash, both domestically and internationally, is an essential aspect of the fight against organised crime and has very substantial benefits in the effective collection of revenue. United States officials informed him that several hundred million dollars were recovered last year from their export/import reporting requirements alone.
Objects of Bill

The principal object of the Bill is to facilitate the administration and enforcement of taxation laws. Further objects of the Bill are to facilitate the administration and enforcement of laws of the Commonwealth, and of a Territory, and to make information collected under the Bill available to State law enforcement authorities to facilitate the administration and enforcement of State laws.
Content of Bill

The Bill provides for the reporting of certain cash transactions and transfers, as well as all suspect transactions. It establishes the Cash Transactions Reports Agency and, in addition, imposes certain obligations on cash dealers and their customers in relation to the operation of accounts.
Cash Transaction Reports

The Bill requires cash dealers, including financial institutions and others, such as bookmakers and casinos, who have the capacity to receive and commingle large amounts of cash, to report cash transactions to which they are a party, and which involve currency in excess of $10,000 to the Director of the Cash Transactions Reports Agency.

All transactions, other than exempt transactions, must be reported. Exemptions may be granted to certain high cash flow businesses, to employers for payroll withdrawals, to Government agencies, and may relate to individual transactions or to certain classes of transactions.

Financial institutions will be required to maintain an exemption register. The Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency will have access to any exemption register and will have power to direct a financial institution to remove or amend any entry in the exemption register maintained by the institution.
Reports Relating to Import and Export Currency

The Government considers it essential to be able to monitor the movement of funds into, and out of, Australia and has therefore provided the Cash Transaction Reports Agency with a monitoring role in relation to the export of foreign currency, and the import of any currency, in excess of $5,000. No other checks are maintained on the movement of funds into, or out of, Australia. As a further check on the movement, and destination of funds, any person in Australia who receives Australian or foreign currency from a place outside Australia will be required to report the receipt of those funds to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency if the value of the currency involved exceeds $5,000.

The Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations confer on customs, and police officers wide-ranging powers to question persons leaving Australia and to inspect their luggage for the purpose of ascertaining currency violations and the Bill provides those officers with similar powers in relation to ensuring that relevant CTR reports have been filed.
Reports of Suspect Transactions

As I indicated earlier, all cash dealers will be obliged to report details of any transaction, regardless of its nature of the amount involved, which the dealer suspects may be relevant to offences against Commonwealth laws.

There are very real concerns on the part of cash dealers that by assisting law enforcement agencies they may leave themselves open to a suit for breach of confidence of defamation. Accordingly, the legislation provides that a cash dealer is immune from such suits when providing information about a suspect transaction to the Director, or an officer investigating the transaction. By providing such information a cash dealer also protects itself against prosecutions for money laundering.
Obligations in Relation to Accounts

Following the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission and the refusal of this Chamber to pass the Australian Card legislation, which would have provided an effective weapon against tax evasion and fraud, the Government considers it essential to include in this Bill provisions dealing with the verification of the identity of persons operating accounts with cash dealers.

The system for the verification of identity provided in this legislation places some obligations on cash dealers and their customers but it should be borne in mind that banks already require some form of identification before opening accounts. The essence of the scheme is a statutory declaration by which an acceptable referee corroborates the identity of a person seeking to open an account. Failure to comply with the verification requirements can result in unverified signatories being prevented from withdrawing funds from the account and, ultimately, that person's interest in the account being forfeited to the Commonwealth. The Bill, of course, contains mechanisms designed to protect the interests of innocent third parties.
Accounts in False Names

The National Crime Authority has expressed grave concern over the proliferation of accounts in false names, which it has rightly identified as a major impediment in the fight against crime. I am sure that other law enforcement agencies share this concern. However, as the law now stands it is not illegal to open, or operate, a bank or other account in a false name. The law enforcement community and the banks have called for this situation to be rectified. This Bill creates offences of opening or operating accounts in false names. These provisions will put an end to the practice of tax cheats and criminals hiding their ill-gotten gains behind a veil of respectability.
Access to CTR Information

The legislation provides that all CTR information is to be provided to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. The Agency is to make the information available to the Commissioner of Taxation on a direct and unrestricted basis. Other law enforcement agencies, including the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and State law enforcement agencies, may also seek access to CTR information. All CTR information may be utilised by relevant agencies for both evidentiary and investigative purposes.
Enforcement

Part IV of the Bill creates offences of structuring transactions and transfers to avoid the reporting requirements, failure to comply with, and providing false and misleading information in purported compliance with, the Bill. An injunction mechanism in relation to breaches of the legislation, particularly where there is a contravention committed by an agency which would otherwise fall within the shield of the Crown, is also available.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill will have only a modest impact on cash dealers required to report cash transaction information as the legislation provides sufficient flexibility to enable the Director of the Agency to develop the most cost-effective measures for cash dealers to record and communicate information to the Agency. In relation to the public sector, the legislation will require the establishment of a Cash Transaction Reports Agency and the purchase of sophisticated computer facilities for the Agency. However the Australian Taxation Office projects an increase in tax revenue alone of some $30m. In addition, the United States' experience indicates that there will be significant criminal law enforcement benefits. Based on annual Agency running costs of $2m per annum (with an extra $1m for establishing computer facilities) the measures are clearly cost-effective.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
