CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1987

This Bill proposes a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and Excise Act 1901, the most important of which are the amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act 1901 (division 2 of part VIII) and the introduction of consequential enforcement and penalty provisions-

To effect the second instalment of the Government's strategy to combat commercial practices designed solely or predominantly to understate the value of imported goods, so as to minimise or avoid customs duty.

With respect to the proposed amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act, which are contained in clause 12 of this Bill, honourable senators will recall that the Government announced in the second reading stage of the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill last sittings that it would be introducing further amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act, to augment the reforms of that first Bill.

The focus of the valuation amendments in this Bill is the rearrangement of the various provisions in division 2 of part VIII of the Customs Act into a more logical and easy to follow sequence, and the highlighting of the various types of costs, charges and agreements relating to goods which will be included or excluded for the purposes of assessing the customs value of the goods. There are also some important new provisions and amendments that are designed to combat minimisation and avoidance practices used by some importers in valuing goods for duty purposes.

Once again, I should emphasise that the Government is not accusing all importers of engaging in avoidance practices. However, experience has shown that some importers have entered arrangements that are designed solely to reduce assessable customs value and thereby reduce duty liability. The Government is therefore of the view that any opportunity for abuse must be removed as soon as it is discovered.

The extent to which minimisation and avoidance practices erode the revenue and existing assistance levels is reflected in the many submissions and complaints received from local manufacturers and producers concerning the commercial advantage which some importers enjoy as a result of their avoidance of correct duty.

Investigations and enquiries by the Australian Customs Service into the activities of importers regarding the valuation of imported goods often lead to the imposition of additional duty and/or litigation being commenced either by the Customs Service or the importer.
Allow me to demonstrate some known avoidance practices which this Bill will eliminate.

The inclusion of inland freight charges in customs value is presently being avoided through the payment of these charges by the purchaser to a third party. Because the vendor invoices the goods to the purchaser at an ex-factory level, the inland freight charges under the current provisions of the act are not included in the customs value, as only payments from the purchaser to the vendor are presently dutiable.

It is important to note that investigations of the industries assistance commission into appropriate levels of industries assistance are based on free-on-board prices (that is, the price of the goods at the point of exportation).

New section 154 in clause 12 of the Bill extensively redefines `Place of export', `foreign inland freight' and `foreign inland insurance' to eliminate the practice of using third party forwarders to avoid duty on inland freight charges.

Another area of avoidance is in overseas freight charges. To achieve the correct customs value for duty purposes, particularly on cost-insurance-&-freight invoices, the Australian Customs Service must be sure that the actual overseas freight paid or payable is deducted from the invoice price. It is the experience of customs that freight costs are being manipulated in various ways, to decrease the customs value (by overstating freight), or to increase the customs value (by understating freight) in order to avoid dumping duties.

There are also practices which indirectly affect the amount of duty paid or payable. The main method here is the payment of rebates by shipping companies to the overseas vendor to purchasers in Australia. The result is that true duty liability is effectively concealed until after importation, resulting in a substantial loss to revenue.

The new definition of overseas freight is designed to give Customs the power to question freight costs shown on invoices and commercial shipping documents to establish the actual freight paid or payable.

A third practice which I will mention briefly is the deduction of so-called buying commissions. Buying commission is an allowable deduction from the price if it is genuine. The problem being experienced by Customs in this area is the difficulty in determining what is a true buying commission. The new section 155 in clause 12 of the Bill is designed to specify situations which preclude agents from holding themselves out to be genuine buying agents.

It is the intention of this legislation to eliminate these practices, and others, which have provided opportunities for avoidance of duty through the minimisation of the value of imported goods. An integral part of these reforms, which was foreshadowed last sittings, is the inclusion of appropriate information-gathering and auditing powers for Customs, to verify information supplied to it, together with new and tougher sanctions for the provision of false or misleading information.

New section 159 in clause 12 imposes a clear responsibility on persons entering goods which are required to be valued to estimate the customs value of the goods, and to provide details on how the value was determined. If Customs is not satisfied with the assessment or supporting information it can seek additional information or undertake an audit of the transaction.

The focus on self-assessment for customs duty purposes was begun in 1985, when the Customs Service introduced streamlined procedures for the entry and clearance of imported goods. These procedures now result in almost 90% of cargo arriving in Australia by either air or sea being cleared from Customs control within 4 hours of the entry being lodged with customs. In many instances the cargo is still being discharged from the aircraft or ship. Further enhancements to the computer system and procedures are planned or being developed and in approximately 2 years it is anticipated that the process will be fully automated.

The streamlined procedures provide for the balance (some 10%) of the import transactions to come under close scrutiny. The transactions are selected using ``risk assessment techniques'' and ``profiles''. This process, similar to that used by the taxation office, will require Customs audit officers to visit importers and closely study commercial documents relevant to the import transaction, to ensure that the goods have been correctly valued for Customs purposes and the appropriate duty paid.

Clause 22 includes a new power for Customs officers to enter premises on which commercial documents relating to information that was supplied to Customs for purposes connected with the entry of goods are kept, to inspect, examine etc. those documents, for the purposes of verifying that information. Clause 25 introduces a new requirement for importers to keep the commercial documents relating to the goods which they have imported for a period of 5 years.
The Government believes both these new provisions will enable the auditing process which I have outlined to be effectively carried out.

The Bill also provides in clause 26 for automatic penalties to be imposed, in instances where duty evasion has been detected. These provisions, which again are similar to those in taxation legislation, will be used in lieu of the seizure of goods and the costly and protracted litigation which inevitably follows such actions.
Financial Impact Statement

The financial impact of the valuation amendments contained in this Bill are considerable. While it cannot be quantified to any exact degree, I will endeavour to show by example that the loss to the revenue by use of such practices cannot be ignored.

In regard to third party inland freight agreements, if the motor vehicle industry of one exporting country changed to ex-factory contacts, and its Australian purchasers employed third-party forwarders, the loss of duty receipts would conservatively amount to $5.2m in one year, seriously affecting the local motor vehicle industry.

Exact quantification of duty short-fall caused by manipulation of overseas freight charges cannot be achieved, due to the various methods employed to manipulate freight amounts. Rebates given by shipping companies to preferred customers are the most common cause of duty short-fall but, because the practice is widespread and most often occurs overseas, it can only be said that the loss to the revenue could amount to many millions of dollars per annum.

By claiming a deduction for a buying agent's commission where the agent is related to the vendor, it was estimated early this year that one major importer had saved about $4m customs duty in a year. If all the major importers adopted the practice, there would be a revenue loss of $90m per annum. The new section 155 proposed in clause 12 lists various things that a genuine buying agent cannot do, and it is estimated that this provision will eliminate many commissions currently being deducted from customs value as buying commissions under the current provisions.

I repeat the statement I made on the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill in the last sittings, that the effect of these practices on local industry has not been quantified, but it is obvious that any erosion of assistance levels by avoidance and minimisation practices can only be detrimental to local industry and employment. These measures are designed to remove this erosion and restore a stable valuation base.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
PETROLEUM EXCISE (PRICES) BILL 1987

The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide for using the volume weighted average price for sales of Bass Strait crude oil as the price basis for levying excise on crude oil produced from the Bass Strait from 1 January 1988, the date on which Australia's crude oil market will be deregulated. This Bill should be read in conjunction with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1987 which is within the portfolio of the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce.

The introduction of this Bill and other associated legislative amendments is an essential step in implementing the Government's decision to deregulate crude oil marketing in Australia with effect from 1 January 1988.

Deregulation will permit all of Australia's crude oil producers and refiners to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell without Government involvement. The Government believes that this freeing of the crude oil market will optimise Australia's future crude oil self sufficiency consistent with the efficient allocation of resources.

The deregulation decision means that the Allocation Scheme for crude oil and Import Parity Pricing will be abolished, and the Bass Strait Coastal Freight Adjustment Scheme, used to compensate refiners remote from Bass Strait for their higher costs of transporting allocated crude, will then be terminated. Except in times of emergency and subject to other relevant policies, such as the prohibition of exports to South Africa, Australia's crude oil producers will have complete freedom to export as an alternative to selling on the domestic market and refiners will have the freedom to import crude oil.

This decision followed a six-month review of the present import parity pricing and market allocation arrangements. The review took into account the views of State Governments, producers and refiners, trade unions and consumers. It also looked closely at the impact of a free market on crude oil and product prices, Government revenues and the balance of payments.

It was concluded that, in the light of changed circumstances in the overall marketing environment, the benefits of deregulation would now outweigh the costs. The changes included a substantial decline in world oil prices, substantial changes in the Australian exchange rate and balance of payments situation and, above all else, the start of the long anticipated decline in Bass Strait production which, in the absence of major new discoveries, will mean a steady rise in the volume of imported crude oil.

The financial impact of moving to a free market for crude oil will depend on the extent to which crude oil prices fall after deregulation. In a deregulated market, average Bass Strait crude oil prices could be expected initially to fall between $A1 and $A4 from what they would have been under import parity pricing. A price fall in the middle of this range, of say $A2.50 per barrel, would result, when passed through to the consumer, in petrol prices falling by around 1.3c per litre. Although this could mean a drop in government revenue from the crude oil excise of about $100m in 1987-88 and $168m in 1988-89 the Government is committed to not offsetting this reduced revenue by compensating adjustments to petroleum product excise, so that the full benefit of any crude oil price reductions is passed on to the consumer. This potential drop in revenue was, of course, taken into account as part of the Budget considerations.

In reaching the decision to deregulate the crude oil market the Government considered the previously expressed concerns of the parties affected. Small producers, with production of less than 5,000 barrels per day, were concerned that they would be disadvantaged after deregulation because of their small production volumes, remoteness from infrastructure and lack of marketing skills. It was decided that the best way of providing support for the existing small producers was to obtain assurances from refiners that they will continue to lift the output of small producers in a timely manner and at fair market prices. Responses have been given by refiners that indicate these conditions will be met. In addition, small producers will now have options other than to sell to refiners. These will include selling to large producers and pipeline owners or having them act as marketing agents, using the services of commodity brokers or trading companies, forming selling co-operatives or consortia or exporting their oil. Indeed all producers, small or large, may well find opportunities in a free market which were not available or considered in a regulated market.

Assurances have also been obtained from refiners that deregulation would not result in the closure of any Australian refinery and refiners will maintain their existing arrangements for Australian flag shipping, albeit with some changes to shipping patterns.

Although it is not possible to be sure of the balance of payments effects of deregulation in advance, it is likely that the net effect on the value of imports and exports of crude oil is likely to be either neutral or positive. Major refiners have argued that deregulation will give Australian refiners access to different grades of imported crude oil suitable for their technologically advanced refineries at prices significantly below current domestic rates. Consequently some higher quality Australian crude oil will be exported but this should be at higher prices than the imports, resulting in a net balance of payments gain.

Other opportunities that oil industry analysts have identified as potentially flowing from deregulation are in the export of refined products based on Australia's sophisticated refineries, and excellent local gasoline feedstock. Also deregulation could open the way for further foreign investment in Australian oil exploration and development.

As part of moving to the free market and at the same time maintaining the flow of revenue to the Commonwealth, an excise system for crude oil based on prices achieved in the free market is required rather than one based on the Government imposed import parity price. This will ensure that the final price base for excise will not be higher than the average prices received by the producers. The crude oil excise rates will be unchanged from those currently in force.

This Bill sets out the system of calculating those prices. It is directed towards oil production from the Bass Strait as this is currently the only production area producing excisable oil. Production from areas on-shore will become excisable in the event that production exceeds the 30 million barrel excise free threshold. The price basis for excising such onshore oil production will be considered at the appropriate time.

The basic principle of the proposed new crude oil excise system is that excise will be levied on crude oil from Bass Strait using the volume weighted average of realised f.o.b. prices of all sales in a calendar month-referred to in the Bill as volware prices. The basis for volware prices will be the realised price of oil at the point of entry for home consumption. This is the price of the oil as it is loaded on a ship at Long Island Point and Crib Point. For pipeline transactions, it will be the realised pipe inlet prices at Long Island Point. The price will be based on payment within 15 days, with an allowance for the extended credit terms in excess of 15 days. Where the contracts for the sale of oil include shipping costs incurred after the point of entry for home consumption and to be borne by the producer, then those shipping costs attributable to actual shipments will be deductible from the contract price. They will include freight, insurance, wharfage and other port charges at the port of destination, demurrage at the delivery end which falls to the producer under a c.i.f. contract and is clearly not caused by the producer, lightering at the port or destination, cargo inspection costs, heating of the cargo on the ship and bunkers.

The Bill makes provision for the determination of three prices for each month of sales. The first, the reference price, will be an estimate of the volware price made before the beginning of the month in question and will be used to calculate the producer's initial excise liability and payments for that month. This price will be based on the most recent interim volware price that has been set, and adjusted for other appropriate factors such as movements in world market prices for crude oil and changes in $A/$US exchange rate. The second, the interim volware price, will be calculated not later than one month after the end of the month in which the oil is sold, based on information provided by the producers about their sales in the month. Once determined, it will replace the reference price as the basis for excise calculations. Third, as some of that information may still be provisional, after six months, or earlier if final information is available, a final volware price for the month will be determined. Once determined, this final volware price will replace the interim volware price and will be the basis of the producers' final excise liability. The method of calculating the transaction prices for use in establishing volware prices will be set out in regulations.

Each of these prices will be notified to the producers and the Australian Customs Service, and the producers' excise liabilities will be adjusted as appropriate in subsequent excise payments. Because of their commercial sensitivity the prices will not be published. As a result of the progressive adjustments to the producers' excise liabilities and payments following the determinations of volware prices, there should not be substantial amounts of excise rebates or additional excise liability outstanding for long periods of time.

The Bill contains provisions requiring the producers to provide the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with the information required to calculate these prices within a time limit to be specified in the Gazette. There are also provisions for auditing of the information.

Basing the excise on an average price gives the producers an incentive to maximise the price they receive above the average and therefore to reduce their effective excise rate. However, the Bill also has provisions to give Ministers the power to determine the price for any sale when any part of the sales transaction is considered not to be at `arm's length' and a price has been arranged which would reduce the revenue due.

This Bill provides for an effective and equitable system of collecting excise on crude oil production. It is a major component in the implementation of the Government's decision to deregulate the Australian crude oil market.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, principally to incorporate into that Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and early in this sittings, and to give effect to changes to the excise arrangements for crude oil that follow from the Government's decision to deregulate crude oil marketing with effect from 1 January 1988.

The proposed deregulation arrangements contained in clauses 8 to 10 inclusive of the Bill, amend the Excise Tariff Act to change the basis of calculating the excise due on the production of crude oil from Bass Strait from one based on the import parity price to one based on the volume weighted average prices realised for crude oil sales by the Bass Strait producers, as determined according to the provisions of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill 1987, for which my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has carriage.

On 21 June the then Minister for Resources and Energy announced the Government's decision to completely deregulate crude oil marketing with effect from 1 January 1988. This will permit refiners and all crude oil producers to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell without Government involvement.

The Government believes that moving to a free market for crude oil will optimise Australia's future crude oil self sufficiency consistent with the efficient allocation of resources. This move will enable the Australian crude oil industry to develop strongly in future for the benefit of the Australian community.

From 1 January 1988 the Government will no longer determine import parity prices as the basis for transactions of domestic crude oil and the determination of excise. Clause 8 of this Bill provides for excise to be determined on the basis of volume weighted average of realised prices for sales of Bass Strait crude oil, known as the volware price.

These prices will be determined each month by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy under the provisions of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill. The initial excise liabilities of the crude oil producers for each month will be calculated on the basis of reference prices notified to the producers and the Australian Customs Service. These prices will be based on recent volware prices and other factors such as movements in world oil market prices for crude oil and changes in exchange rates. Interim volware prices for the month will also be calculated on the basis of sales information provided by the producers and notified during the following month. The producers' initial excise liabilities will be adjusted from those calculated using the reference price, and thereafter, interim prices will form the basis of excise liability until final volware prices are determined.

The provisions of this Bill introduce arrangements which will allow adjustments to be made to the producers' crude oil excise liability which result from using reference, interim and final volware prices. These arrangements will mean that the adjustments to the producers excise liabilities will be effected automatically following the determination of the volware prices, and thereby avoid the situation whereby excise liability could have remained outstanding for long periods.

The import parity price adjustments, at clauses 13, 15 and 16 of the Bill, continue the Government's policy since 1 March 1986 to fully offset changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalty by across the board changes in excises payable on petroleum products. The net result of this policy is that as crude oil prices change, Government revenues remain the same overall and petrol price changes are kept to a minimum.

On 1 May 1987, the IPP of indigenous crude oils were decreased to reflect an appreciation of the Australian dollar against the US dollar, and the excise rates on refined petroleum products were correspondingly increased with effect from 16 May 1987 (clause 13).

On 1 July 1987 and 1 August 1987 the IPP of indigenous crude oils were increased to reflect upward movements in world oil prices and, consistent with the Government's policy, the excise rates on refined petroleum products were reduced with effect from 18 July 1987 (clause 15) and 15 August 1987 (clause 16) respectively.

Clauses 6, 8 and 14 of the Bill give effect to the Government's decisions following its review of new petroleum taxation arrangements, to remove distortions and disincentives to petroleum exploration and development in Australia.

The review follows the Government's undertaking at the time of the Energy 2000 conference in September 1986, where the oil industry pressed strongly for the removal of all secondary taxation on petroleum production, arguing that the existing taxation regime was making Australia an unattractive place to invest in exploration and development.

The Government's review established that some changes to the existing arrangements are necessary, given the reduction in the level of world crude oil prices and continuing uncertainty in their future levels, to ensure that Australia can continue to attract oil exploration and development investment.

The package of concessions will apply to both existing crude oil production and new projects where excise and royalty apply, namely Bass Strait, North West Shelf and on-shore areas. Elsewhere off-shore, the resource rent tax regime announced in 1984 will continue to apply. The key elements in the new excise package are as follows:

Confirmation that the maximum rate of `old' oil excise will not be restored to 87 per cent of the import parity price and that there will be a progressive lowering of the top marginal rate of excise on such oil from 80 per cent to 75 per cent over the next 3 years;
exemption from excise of the first 30 million barrels of crude oil production from new off-shore projects where excise and royalty apply;
exemption from excise of the first 30 million barrels of crude oil produced from onshore fields;
exemption from excise of condensate marketed separately from crude oil; and
exemption from excise of LPG produced onshore.

Clause 14 of the Bill also includes an increase in the excise duty rate on aviation gasoline. This follows extensive consultation with the general aviation industry on the most appropriate cost recovery and charging arrangements to apply in 1987-88, and the Government's decision to adopt a suggestion made by the industry to place a surcharge on aviation gasoline (avgas) fuel excise. This proposal, which sets the surcharge at 3.9c a litre, has the full support of all the major general aviation organisations. The surcharge replaces the previous fixed annual air navigation charges which had been payable by general aviation aircraft. In addition to the surcharge general aviation avgas aircraft will pay landing charges at the major airports scheduled for transfer to the Federal Airports Corporation. General aviation aircraft using aviation kerosene (avtur) will pay landing charges for all operations on the same basis as airline aircraft.
The final major inclusion in this Bill, at clause 5, effects a change to the operation of section 6a of the Act, relating to the automatic indexation of rates of duty.

Presently the Act provides for rates of duty to be adjusted on the 1st of February and 1st of August in accordance with movements in the consumer price index. This is dependent however, on the Australian Statistician publishing the index number at least seven days before these dates. If this does not occur, which has been the majority of cases, the new rate is determined by Gazette notice.
Uncertainty concerning the commencement date of the new rates is causing undue disruption to business involved with implementing the new rates.

To simplify procedures the proposed amendment will provide that in cases where the Australian Statistician does not publish the index number at least five days before 1 February or 1 August, then the new rates will take effect five days after the Australian Statistician publishes the index number.
Financial Impact Statement
(A) DEREGULATION OF CRUDE OIL MARKETING ARRANGEMENTS (CLAUSES 8-10 INCLUSIVE)

The financial impact on crude oil excise receipts resulting from the proposed arrangements for the deregulated or a free market for crude oil will depend on the extent to which crude oil prices vary after deregulation. In the current international climate and in a deregulated market, average Bass Strait crude oil prices could be expected to fall between $A1-$A4 per barrel from what they would have been under import parity pricing.
On the basis of a price fall of $A2.50 per barrel, the drop in Government revenue in 1987-88 and 1988-89 is expected to be about $100m and $168m respectively.
There will be no offsetting product excise adjustment to recoup revenue foregone by the Government as a result of any drop in crude oil prices following deregulation.
(B) IMPORT PARITY PRICE ADJUSTMENTS (CLAUSES 13, 15 AND 16 (b to g))

The increase in refined petroleum product excise rates due to the changes in the import parity prices effective from 16 May 1987 is expected to result in an increase in revenue of about $20m in 1986-87. The decrease in refined petroleum product excise rates effective from 1 July 1987 and 1 August 1987 is expected to result in decreases in revenue of about $7.2m and $82.7m respectively in 1987-88.
The changes in the excise rates following changes to the import parity prices exactly offset the forecast changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalty.
(C) NEW PETROLEUM TAXATION ARRANGEMENTS (OFFSHORE AND ONSHORE) CLAUSES 6, 8 AND 14 (b to d)

The introduction of the new excise concessions on crude oil and LPG from 1 July 1987 are forecast to reduce Commonwealth and State government revenues by $18m in 1987-88 and by $297m in the five years to 1991-92. Higher production levels as a result of the new concessions will generate additional excise and royalty receipts which are expected to more than compensate for the cost of the concessions based on previous production forecasts by the producers:
In 1987-88, the Commonwealth is forecast to receive an additional $670m; and
In the five years ending 1991-92, the higher production levels will generate an additional $3.2 billion in excise and royalty collections for the Commonwealth and State governments.
(D) AVIATION GASOLINE SURCHARGE (CLAUSE 14 (a))
It is estimated that the surcharge will raise around $3.9m in 1987-88.
(E) AUTOMATIC INDEXATION CHANGES (CLAUSE 5)
The amendments proposed by this clause have no direct financial implications.

The Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill should be seen as part of the implementation of a series of decisions involving defence shipbuilding activities which the Minister for Defence announced on 1 April this year. In that statement, he said that `the Government has decided to offer for sale to commercial organisations a controlling interest in (Williamstown) Dockyard'. Operating under public sector constraints, Williamstown Dockyard is not well structured to remedy these deficiencies and to compete for the full prime contractor role for the new surface combatant or Project Anzac.
Two consortiums are on the short-list of tenderers to buy the Dockyard. They are:

Australian Marine Engineering Corporation, a consortium consisting of Australian Shipbuilding Industries (ASI) of Western Australia, Eglo Engineering of South Australia, ICAL of New South Wales and Thorn-EMI; and

Williamstown Dockyard Consortium, a consortium consisting of Tecnav Pty Ltd (a group of employees at Williamstown Dockyard), Byvest Pty Ltd, a management buyout consultancy firm and McConnell-Dowell, a New Zealand based subsidiary of Inter Pacific Ltd.

Following the evaluation of their bids, the Government will decide which of them is to become the new owners of Williamstown Dockyard. This will be the most significant sale of Commonwealth assets so far undertaken in Australia. It will be significant because:
it will bring about a major restructuring of defence shipbuilding industry; and
it will have long term benefits for the defence budget.

The new owner of Williamstown Dockyard will take over the task of completing the two FFG-7 class frigates that are being built there. They are planned for delivery in 1991 and 1993. With the four FFGs that were built in the U.S.A., and the guided missile destroyers, they will form the first level of capability that was mentioned in the Defence White Paper which Mr Beazley tabled in March this year as able to contribute to a wide range of operations in both low level and more substantial contingencies.

This program of 12 ships is a collaborative one between Australia and New Zealand. It is expected that it will give rise to a resurgence in warship building in Australia and like the submarine project provide a continuing work load to Australian industry for many years to come. These two multi-billion projects demonstrate the Government's resolve to support local industry and to bring new technologies to Australia. Expressions of interest have been called for both the design of the Anzac ship and for the role of the prime contractor for the construction of the ships. The Minister hopes to be in a position to announce the name of the new owner of Williamstown Dockyard and the tenderers for the prime contractor role in the near future.

The Anzac ship project represents the largest shipbuilding program undertaken in Australia since World War II. It demonstrates this Government's commitment to the defence of Australia and its willingness to make the decisions necessary to implement the commitment.

Williamstown Dockyard's work force of some 1,600 are employed under both the Public Service Act and the Naval Defence Act. Neither of these Acts makes provision for mobility between public and private employment. This Bill recognises that there is continuity of employment in this case. It is designed to facilitate the handover of the dockyard to the new owners without the absurdity of making employees eligible for large redundancy payments where there is continuity of employment. were beginning to achieve agreements that could have resolved a number of the continuing problems besetting New South Wales' public hospitals. That, to my mind, seems to be a reasonable summation of the consequence of this Government's cheap public relations stunt to divert from itself the blame on the question of the increasing cost of medical care-and, of course, the increasing cost of Medicare-and to place it on the doctors. I refer the Committee to a survey done in Western Australia by the Western Australian Faculty of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, which showed that many neighbourhood doctors are in a poor financial state. . . . rising overheads, recent changes to Medicare rebates and an increasing proportion of disadvantaged patients contributed to financial problems.
Doctors needed to set a financially-viable fee.
Most GPs gave pensioners and disadvantaged patients a 15 per cent discount on the Government-recommended fee.
This group formed up to 50 per cent of patients in some practices.

In the past, doctors have provided many totally free services. That situation, of course, has been changed by Medicare. There is no doubt that once one has government intervention in this area one gets a mess. We now have the medi-mess-the Medicare mess created by this Government. General practitioners' very survival is being put at threat in many areas. Quite recently, an article in the Bulletin demonstrated the difficult position of general practitioners both in the city and in the country areas of New South Wales. Not only is their survival, and therefore, of course, the quality of medicine available to patients throughout Australia under threat, but also we have this dreadful situation now whereby a bigger and bigger proportion of the cost of medical treatment is to be borne by the patient, including patients who are chronically ill and who in fact have to bear an even greater proportion of the increase than those who are not chronically ill. TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of questions which I would like to ask and they are all related to the economic benefits of the migration program. SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded that, only a couple of weeks ago, I was in Port Augusta at a conference of Aboriginal people. We were considering the process by which migrants can come to this country with $500,000 with virtually no questions asked, whereas the Aborigines are, in many respects, having a hard time. One of the Aborigines present at the conference said, `If we were outside this country, we would never be admitted as migrants'. That comment seemed to me to suggest that we should be looking very closely at the migration program. While it may not be a racist program, it is certainly culturist in that we are prepared to accept into this country those who have developed the same exploitative tendencies as the white people in Australia but we cannot do the right thing by the indigenous people, who have a different culture and an attitude of caring for the land in which they have lived for 40,000 years or more. Yesterday, in furtherance to an answer to a question the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) said:

I have the departmental answer to the honourable senator's question. It reads as follows: The greater proportion of the Government's migration program is directed towards economic benefits and is designed to select skilled migrants to fill labour market needs immediately; business migrants to contribute to economic development; and independent and concessional migrants who are immediately employable, young, skilled and educated. Selection criteria are designed to ensure immediate economic contribution and to minimise social welfare costs. The assessing of employability has regard to the likely language requirements of the specific occupation or employer.

Leaving aside for a moment the question of whether one should use people simply as economic ciphers to be shuffled around from country to country wherever one can make a profit out of them, it seems to me that if one accepts this assertion which has often been made that the migration program is of economic benefit to this country then it behoves those who make that assertion to establish that there are indeed economic benefits. I do not believe that this has been done.

I point to several observations in relation to the migration program. Family reunion is a substantial part of that program at present. Very often in these family reunion programs we are bringing in large numbers of unskilled people who, in fact, contribute overly to the unemployment rate in Australia compared with indigenous Australians. I point also to the fact that in addition to the amount we are considering in relation to the appropriations for this Department some $137m per year is at the moment being repatriated out of Australia to other countries in the form of pensions to former migrants.

I believe that there is no linkage at all between the stated economic objectives of this Government, namely to increase exports, and the migration program. It is well known that primary industry is becoming more and more capital intensive and less labour intensive and, indeed, fewer and fewer people are working on farms producing primary products. I believe that approximately two-thirds of Australia's primary production is exported. To the extent that we increase our population, the proportion of primary produce that we export falls. Our other major export industry of recent years-minerals-is also a very capital intensive industry and one in which we do not need large numbers of people to produce exports. I am not sure whether the importing of people is aiding the declared economic requirements of this country.

Another point I would like to make bears on a question I asked Senator Walsh yesterday in relation to gross national product. The gross national product counts many costs as benefits. This was a point which Senator Walsh conceded. Most of the migrants who come to Australia settle in urban areas. As these are very large areas already, these people tend to settle on the periphery. The population geographically expands outwards. We build more roads and more houses, we provide more telephones, we use more electricity, more water, more gas, et cetera. Those are costs which are borne by ordinary Australians. For instance, those people living further away from Adelaide must travel further to work. The costs for those Australians increase. The cost of electricity goes up. The cost of providing the water supply goes up. Those costs appear in the national accounts as additions. So by that measure of gross national product it is certainly true that we are becoming better off. But, that measure itself is misleading, as Senator Walsh conceded yesterday. Those costs should be put in a costs column and not in a benefits column. I think it is the perception of the majority of people in Australia, particularly in the cities, that they are becoming worse off. That decrease in the quality of life is largely to do with population size. That population size is being augmented by a migration program which is being supported by the Government.

We hear a lot about the need to deepen the capital investment in this country rather than to widen the capital investment. To the extent that the migration program causes more building, particularly home building, it is simply a capital widening; it is not a capital deepening. The provision of more houses for migrants does not help the housing situation for those people already in this country.

For a variety of reasons I think it seems to be clear that a good case can be made for the claim that the migration program is, in fact, detrimental to the economic well-being of Australia. I therefore call on the Minister to provide the evidence which lies behind the assertion which she made yesterday and which has often been made by people both in government and in opposition-that the migration program is indeed of economic benefit to Australia.

I will just summarise. Not all visaed principal applicants will ultimately come to Australia, though recent experience suggests that at least 95 per cent will, and those who do may bring more or less money than indicated at their interview, for a variety of reasons. There is also an artificial upper limit of $9.9m for the funds item and this is likely to affect the figures for the business migration category in particular. However, the data do provide a guide as to the absolute magnitude of migrants' funds in relation to other balance of payments aggregates and to the relativities between categories and posts.

The aggregate amount available for transfer by migrants visaed in 1986-87 was $2,110m, a substantial amount relative to other balance of payments figures. For example, the amount spent by tourists in Australia in 1986-87 was $2,528m. However, once tourist funds leaving the country are taken into account, the net figure in 1986-87 was a debit of $429m. Therefore, net migrant transfers, on the other hand, were an estimated credit of $l1,351m.

The average amount a principal applicant visaed during 1986-87 had to transfer to Australia was $41,300. I emphasise that that was taking all categories of migrants. There was considerable variation between policy categories though, with business migration and special eligibility categories being well above average and, of course, family migration and refugees being obviously well below average. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) for her reply and those figures of which I was aware. I simply point out that that study is being done by conventional economists with conventional accounting methods which is exactly the point that I was making. I point out that many of the costs are counted as benefits, particularly, in relation to housing. It really does not benefit Australians to build more houses if those houses are not being built for Australians. That applies to the so-called increase in consumption which is going on.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I make is in relation to the Minister's comments about decreasing the average age of Australians because of the younger age of migrants, on average. I am sure she would be aware that it costs much more to educate people than it does to look after them when they are old. The claim that we need to be concerned because people are getting older and we have an aging population that we need to look after, is, in fact, a furphy. It is far more difficult and expensive to look after a young population than an old population. The increase in the average age from roughly 31 to 37 which, I think, would be the age at equilibrium, would produce a better economic situation for Australia than what we have at the moment.

Finally, I simply make the point that it is well known that Australians have, as it were, voted democratically with their reproductive behaviour. They have declared to other Australians and to this Government what they want for Australia. The average fertility per woman is down to about 1.84 children. It seems to me to be a peculiar denial of the democratic process that the Government now seeks to impose on people who have declared their intention through their fertility behaviour, whether they like it or not, an even larger population on the country. Would the Minister care to comment on whether it is democratic to go against the declared wishes-not declared at the ballot box, but declared even more fundamentally through the way parents have behaved in producing children-by imposing a further 120,000 people per year on an unwilling Australian population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a question relating to an item in the Appropriation Bill on accommodation services for refugees and migrants at migrant centres and flats. These alterations have been described by the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) as improvements to migrant accommodation and they have involved the closure and sale of migrant hostels in Perth and Brisbane so that new arrivals can now be housed in self-contained accommodation. It is recognised that the institutionalised living in the migrant hostels was not always satisfactory for migrants even though they were there for only a limited period. Afterwards migrants did move on to self-contained flats if they so wished before being in the situation where they could maintain themselves in their own housing. It is stated that this self-contained accommodation can be provided at a much lower cost. It would be interesting to know, though I do not pose that specific question, at this stage how much lower that cost would be, because it was said by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) in his Press release that the change in emphasis from old-style hostel living to self-contained accommodation would not mean a reduction in the ancillary services provided for new settlers and that the same range of assistance would be provided; only its location and method of delivery would change.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask the Minister for Local Government how the same sorts of services to newly-arrived migrants can be provided in this situation. In Perth, for example, when the Graylands hostel is closed down, migrants will be moved to government-owned blocks of flats in Tuart Hill, Osborne Park and Beaconsfield. These are three separate suburbs in Perth. How can services with regard to on-arrival English programs for migrants in hostels, child care services provided in situ in the hostel and information and other services provided by bilingual information officers be given if migrants are to be spread, as in Perth, over three separate suburbs? How can all these services be provided and the costs lowered at the same time? I notice that expenditure in this area in 1986-87 was $8,871,000. The estimate for 1987-88 is $8,371,000. The saving is $400,000, as per the tables. Does that include the costs of these extra services? People who work with migrants in Perth have approached me, saying that they are very worried about these matters. They have posed such questions as this: migrants obviously do not have cars immediately on arrival in Perth, but the bus services in Perth leave a lot to be desired. Are women who require the early arrival English classes and who have to take their children to child centres to be provided with taxis? How will all this be managed? It seems to me to be a very difficult exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of points that Senator Coulter made and also to ask the Minister a couple of questions. In the first place, I would like to make it very clear that the Opposition does not share Senator Coulter's view that immigration is too high. On the contrary, the Opposition is strongly in favour of immigration, and always has been.
—I was asking a question.

—Senator Coulter is saying, `I was not really saying that too many migrants are still coming in. All I was asking was whether it was democratic to bring them in'. I have not heard many more ridiculous propositions than that specious nonsense. The emotive suggestion that it may well be undemocratic strikes me as a clear statement of a position which, I must say, is not the Opposition's position. We should make that clear. If it is not the position of the Australian Democrats, I hope that a spokesman from the Democrats will give an unequivocal commitment to support at least the present level of immigration so that we will not have this double-talking nonsense that Senator Coulter is now appearing to undertake.
—It is not nonsense. Why do you support immigration?

—I will come to that. As the good old political phrase goes, `I am glad you asked me that question'. First, I will deal with a couple of matters relating in particular to the business migration program. I thank the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) for providing information, in response to Senator Coulter, about the $500m-odd. I am really speaking in response to questions my cousin, Senator Peter Baume, asked in the Senate Estimates Committee because he is not able to be present in the chamber due to parliamentary business elsewhere. He had asked where the half a million dollars was going, for example. In 1984-85, visaed business migrants said that they were bringing $151m; $242m in 1985-86; and $507.4m in 1986-87. According to the response to Senator Peter Baume, indications from the Department are that most business migrants understate the funds they are transferring to Australia. So the figures could well be more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern, and that of Senator Peter Baume, relates to where the money is going. He was concerned about what industries it was going into. The only information the Department has about investment intentions of people with money coming into Australia under this program relates to the period before April 1985. The Government simply seems to be extrapolating that information forward, which does not seem to me to be an adequate or coherent way of keeping check on what is a very significant program which presumably has been instituted to bring benefits to Australia. We do not know exactly in what way these benefits are coming to us because the Government has not provided an adequate monitoring system.

Under the arrangements entered into before April 1985-and it is evident from the list of figures that there was not all that much before April 1985-something like 40 per cent was going into manufacturing industry. In other words, it appears that this program is of great benefit to an area of Australian industry which is in desperate need of investment funds. If these figures are being maintained, that program is clearly of some benefit to our balance of payments because, as has been repeatedly pointed out, the continual fall in investment in manufacturing industry under this Government has been disastrous for us in that it has limited our ability to replace imports and certainly has damaged our capacity to increase exports.

What concerns me about the accuracy of these figures is that they do not indicate any investment in tourism. I would have thought that tourism would probably be one of the major areas in which investment from business migrants would have taken place, as they would be experts in dealing with people from their country of origin. I ask the Minister to give her attention to seeing to what extent there can be greater monitoring of at least the investment intentions of these people. I find it hard to believe that half of one per cent of the money, according to the survey, brought in by business migrants simply ends up in the finance industry. Clearly that is nonsense. I am not in any way attacking the program. I am simply saying that we need more information about it.

Another bit of information I would like concerns the Australian Labor Party's immigration and ethnic affairs policy. In June 1987, during the recent election campaign, the policy stated that the Labor Party was committed to enhancing and strengthening the various advisory bodies presently operating. That was its election commitment. I wonder whether the Minister would be prepared to tell us what her Party has done or intends to do to put that commitment into effect.

In response to Senator Coulter, in the few minutes remaining, I just say that a very sound case is made for the maintenance of immigration to Australia in the recent publication that was tabled yesterday, Australia's population trends and prospects 1987. That document was produced by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It notes:

The success of immigration policies in promoting growth has been substantial. In Australia, post-War immigration is estimated to have contributed, directly and indirectly through births, over 60 per cent of total growth.
In the future, as natural increase declines and populations age, immigration is likely to take on an even more significant role.

In defence of that proposition I think it is important to recognise, as Senator Coulter has pointed out, that there have been changes in birth patterns. There was a baby boom; now there is a baby recession. Recessions follow booms and vice versa. To make an assumption that people have adopted an immutable position-that is not meant in a sexual sense-on whether the population should increase at a particular rate, as Senator Coulter has done, does not appear to be coherent. In any event, I think if Senator Coulter were to examine the issue properly he would recognise that economic considerations play a very important part in people's decisions on whether they will have a family of two or more offspring. To attempt to suggest that because the reproduction rate is about 1.85 it therefore indicates a determined view that we should not increase the population of Australia is not only bunkum, it is absolutely pathetic bunkum. I am not trying to advise the Minister how to answer Senator Coulter, but Senator Coulter did invite me to make the point. The publication on Australia's population trends and prospects put out by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs deals with this specific issue very well indeed. It points out that not simply in Australia but in the rest of the world one of the most important demographic issues is the rapid growth in the number of elderly. Issues associated with aging already represent major challenges to planners in developed countries. The report goes on to say:
The small generations being born now will have to support very large numbers of aged dependants in 30 to 50 years time.

So quite apart from all the other benefits and obvious considerations-business investments, providing new investment and so on, providing skilled workers at a time of shortage-there is the specific consideration about the impact on the makeup of our population in age terms. The report continues:

Australia's population is projected to age at about the same rate as those of other developed countries . . . By 2025 it is likely to have a median age of 38.4 years (compared with 31.0 years in 1986). This is about the same as the present median age in the Federal Republic of Germany.

In Australia a key aspect of ageing will be the march of the baby boom generations up the age pyramid. By 2025 nearly all these people will be aged 65 years or older. They will make up about 17.6 per cent of the population compared with 10.5 per cent for the 65 years and over age group in 1986.
That is a very significant change. Instead of only 10 per cent of the population being 65 or over, by 2025 about 17.6 per cent will be because of that baby boom. The publication continues:
Perhaps more significant, given their greater demands on health and welfare programs, will be growth in the number of people aged 75 years and over.

We have to recognise that taxpayers are the people who have to provide health and welfare programs for the aged. That is not being critical of the aged; it is simply stating the fact. If we end up with a far greater proportion of our population in the aged category the burden on the rest of the community will be so much higher. The publication goes on to say that over the 1986 to 2025 period the aged dependency ratio in Australia is projected to increase by about three times the decline in another important ratio, the youth dependency ratio. Interestingly, it is far cheaper to support youth than it is to support the elderly. The report goes on:

The aged dependency ratio is projected to jump not only because of the movement of the baby boom generations over 65 years, but also because at this time growth in the population of labour force age is projected to grow slowly. Without immigration growth it would be negative.
In other words, there would be a fall in the number of people in the work force providing the taxes to provide services to a greater proportion of people who are aged.
The report continues:

The impact of immigration is to add proportionately large numbers to the labour force age groups, thereby slowing the rate of increase in the aged dependency ratio . . . by bolstering numbers in the labour force, immigration has the potential to alleviate the burden per worker which will be imposed as a result of the baby boom generations moving into aged dependency in the decades after 2012.
So it seems that all this rational, coherent stuff from the Department which Senator Coulter obviously does not like--

TALK.START.PARA: —Irrational and incoherent.
—It is in fact rational and coherent and I believe it totally demolishes what Senator Coulter said. Another interesting point is the level of urbanisation in Australia. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia the level of urbanisation is not likely to change dramatically from the very high 86 per cent as at the 1981 Census. Of particular importance will be the future growth of Australia's five largest cities. . . . Growth of these cities has been slow recently . . . largely as a result of increased out-migration. The factors underlying this trend include changing employment patterns away from manufacturing, which is concentrated in the big cities, to the service sector, which is more decentralised; growing numbers rejecting high density city living; and a growing retirement population seeking more favourable environments in which to settle . . . Counteracting the effects of internal migration will be immigration, which tends to add proportionately large numbers to the major cities.

This therefore maintains the use of the infrastructures already built up. So in economic terms immigration overall is providing a very useful service which the Opposition strongly supports. It favours at least present rates of immigration and certainly would reject any suggestion that there should be any diminution, particularly on the basis Senator Coulter seemed to be suggesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume is certainly capable of quoting a lot of figures, but not of arguing very coherently on the basis of those figures. I simply draw attention to the document from which he was quoting and ask him to have a look at the sections which seem to deal praisingly with cities such as Mexico City and forecast that Australian cities are going to become rather like Mexico City. The document is full of assertions that it is a good thing for populations to grow, but nowhere is there any substantial argument as to why that is the case. It would be a good thing if Australia's population got smaller because Australia is an overpopulated country. Over the last 200 years we have substantially wrecked this environment. The damage to the environment, quite simply, is a product of the number of people acting on that environment multiplied by the per capita demands. Senator Baume belongs to a party that would increase those per capita demands. Rather stupidly, it seeks to increase the number of people in Australia. I simply put the question: What happens when Australia finishes up like Hong Kong and we have people virtually dripping off the edges? Clearly, there is a point at which population growth must stop. One cannot endlessly go on increasing population.

SPEECH.PARA: The logical question to ask is: At what point do we stop population growth? I suggest that the point at which it should be stopped is when we have a comfortable, sustainable lifestyle, and that is what the Australian Democrats are on about. The lifestyle which we are now leading is not sustainable; we are wrecking our environment. The question must be asked: when do we want to stop? I believe that a case has not been made that increasing our population is of benefit to us. The assertion by Senator Michael Baume that the economy has grown since the Second World War, since we have had an active migration program, is certainly true. But if one brings in more people, of course the population will grow. If each person brought in has an income of x dollars a year, the total revenue and the economy will grow. That does not mean that each individual person in the community is better off. As I have already shown, much of that increasing cost-and Senator Walsh admitted this yesterday-of providing the infrastructure appears in the national accounts as a benefit. But it is not a benefit at all; simply to cover a greater area of land with bitumen and concrete and building houses on it is not necessarily of benefit to people living in Australia.

I draw attention again to the document from which Senator Michael Baume has quoted. If he has a close look at that document he will see that two countries that have lower population growth rates than Australia-notably Japan and West Germany-have done remarkably better economically, using the same criteria which his Party would choose to use in regard to benefit. Even if one agreed that there had been an economic benefit to Australia since the Second World War through the migration program, it would not necessarily follow that that economic benefit would continue in the future. Industrial development was clearly beneficial, but it is not necessarily clear that continued industrial development is beneficial. Moreover, it does not necessarily logically follow that Australia could not have achieved considerable economic benefit, as Japan has, without population growth. It could have been achieved in other ways. I suggest that the investments which now have to be made in such things as roads, housing, extra telephones, water supply and those sorts of things, would be better spent in deepening the investment in the sorts of areas that Senator Michael Baume has talked about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly thank Senator Michael Baume for his very rational contribution to this debate.
—His what?

—His rational contribution. I thought that earlier Senator Coulter raised some genuine concerns about economic issues, and I provided the figures for him. But I find it rather disturbing that when Senator Coulter talked about infrastructure needs, he said-I believe I am quoting him correctly-that bringing in migrants will not create extra benefits for Australians. I remind Senator Coulter that we are bringing in migrants to be part of Australia as a multicultural society. We do not see people who arrive in this country as being different and that, if we are providing housing for this group or that group, this should be a question for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of some of the fairly unfortunate comments that have been made in this chamber this week, it is rather surprising to me to hear an Australian Democrat also raise some of these doubts about our immigration policy. That is why I take the somewhat unusual stance of commending Senator Michael Baume. It must be acknowledged that this week the Liberal Party of Australia has made it absolutely clear that it supports the immigration policies of this Government and that we have a bipartisan approach to immigration. We may have differences of opinion about certain procedures but, in essence, we have a bi-partisan approach. That is what multicultural Australia expects and is entitled to. Therefore, I will not refer again to the comments of Senator Stone and Senator Sheil. They have been given sufficient airing, I am sure, for those two senators.

I must say I was rather surprised to hear Senator Coulter say that somehow fertility control is related to parents' desire for zero population growth. I certainly know any number of women who choose not to have children or to limit their families, which, of course, is totally their choice. But if I asked them whether they were making that determination, that choice, on the basis of zero population growth, I doubt whether they would comment in the affirmative. People choose their family size for a variety of reasons. I do not believe that the majority are choosing to limit their families-or, indeed, not to have children-because of some commitment to zero population growth. I certainly cannot accept the theory that Senator Coulter put forward this evening.

As to the idea that Australia is overpopulated, I think many people in this place would like to take issue with Senator Coulter on that statement. When one looks at Australia's position in the Asian and Pacific region, I doubt whether, if one said outside Australia that Australia was overpopulated, one would be able to convince too many people. Frankly, I doubt whether one would be able to convince many people in Australia that Australia was overpopulated.

The other point that concerns me was Senator Coulter's statement that, in regard to immigration issues, we had to consider the importance of maintaining a comfortable, sustainable lifestyle. Again, I cannot see the relationship between whatever definition he may have of comfortable, sustainable lifestyle and Australia's immigration policies. I do not believe that it is socially responsible, given Australia's commitment to a number of humanitarian and refugee programs, for us to talk about a comfortable, sustainable lifestyle. In fact, I think it is a gross insult to many people who seek to come to this country so that they can enjoy so many benefits that this country has to offer. I say to Senator Coulter that a number of us in this place-and, I am sure, a number of people listening to the broadcast of the proceedings-will wait with bated breath to find out whether the views that he holds on over population, in regard to the limiting of the immigration program, are shared by other Australian Democrats, or whether this is another example of the one-man band approach to policy development within the Australian Democrats.

Earlier, Senator Jenkins asked me a question about translator and interpreter services in Western Australia. As I said, the Commonwealth has offered to assist the States in setting up the services. Recent advice from Western Australia is that it is interested in further discussions. The Department proposes to take up those discussions shortly, with a view to finalising the matter before the next financial year. So it does seem that Western Australia will take up the offer that has been made by the Commonwealth for some time.

In regard to Senator Jenkins's other question relating to migrant accommodation, the migrant centre network which is now used principally for migrant refugees was streamlined by the closure of five centres late in 1985. The emphasis of the Government is on rebuilding self-contained units, which we believe to be more beneficial to people settling in Australia. Rather than their being located in one place, it is far more appropriate for them to have the opportunity to move into different areas of the cities or, indeed, regional areas.

Mr R. Vale

Vale, PO 3721, Darwin 5794. Mr Vale is the Speaker of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan's letter more or less refers to Mr Vale's letter of 24 August to the `Hon. R. J. L. Hawke'. The letter from Senator Ryan does not carry the courtesy title of Hon., to which Mr Vale is entitled. There is no recognition that he is the Speaker of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and, as such, is the figurehead of the Northern Territory people. There is no reference to the fact that the letter is in response to a motion moved in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. The reply has obviously been spewed out by a computer. It is something which has obviously been sent to thousands of people who objected to the Australia Card. If people take the time to look at the copy of the letter that has been incorporated in Hansard, they will see that it is just like thousands of others that Ministers of this Government sent out on the Australia Card. I believe that the way in which this correspondence has been handled and the manner in which it has been put down is an insult to the people of the Northern Territory and that this action deserves an apology both from the Prime Minister and from Senator Ryan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Australia Post:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Postal Commission's employment practices do not include any height, weight or weight-for-height medical standards. The only circumstances where weight or height are considered for employment purposes, given that an applicant is otherwise in good health, would be where extremes of weight or height would expose an employee to a hazard or risk or injury to himself or herself, other employees, or the general public (for example, an applicant for a driving position who may be too small to reach the operating controls of a vehicle). In such cases, practical tests should be used to determine suitability for employment. For superannuation purposes, however, Australian Postal Commission employees are required to be members of the Commonwealth superannuation Fund. This fund has its own General Medical standard for Superannuation which includes a weight-for-height standard which an employee should meet. An applicant may be assessed as suitable for employment even though that applicant does not meet the General Medical Standard. In such cases, a Benefit Classification Certificate is issued by the Commissioner for Superannuation for not meeting the particular standard concerned.
(2) Not applicable, for the reasons given in (1).

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Beef Imports to the United States of America

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 October 1987 (Hansard, page 723) Senator Tambling asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question without notice concerning beef imports to the USA. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is not in a position to influence US or Japanese policy regarding their inspection standards for their domestic meat. Equally, the US Government does not interfere with Australian domestic standards for locally produced meat. The Government does, however, negotiate standards with both the US and Japanese Governments regarding the standards for Australian meat imported into these countries.

As far as a comparison between the standards for domestic and imported meat in the US is concerned, the US Federal Meat Inspection Act requires that exporting countries apply conditions equivalent to those applying in the United States. Similarly, the Japanese Government requires exporting countries to comply with its own Food Sanitation Law.

Testing of foodstuffs imported into Australia is a State and Territory responsibility and the Commonwealth is only concerned with the quarantine aspects. I am not aware of any testing currently carried out on imported US beef.

However, a Working Group on Imported Foods was recently set up by the Commonwealth with the aim of looking at whether the present control systems on imported foods are adequate and if there was a need for more Commonwealth involvement in this area.

Australian standards for pesticides are comparable to those of the US. Both countries base the Maximum Residue Limit (MRL) on the Codex International Standard although in some cases the Australian MRL is more stringent.

ANSWER.PARA: A total of $41,998,500 has been provided in the 1987-88 Budget for the RAS. This amount consists of the following components:
Continuing subsidy1 commitments under Part A
(1) The Scheme provides for a subsidy established in any one year to be paid for a total of 7 years so that farmers may receive assistance for up to 7 years.

Under Part A of the Scheme eligible farmers who have been unable to obtain commercial finance at reasonable market rates are assisted to return to viability with concessional finance. The funds provided by the Commonwealth under this Part are used to provide an interest subsidy of up to 50% of the cost of borrowings.

Under Part C there are two measures, Household Support and Rehabilitation, which aim to alleviate the financial hardship of farmers who cannot be returned to viability under Part A and who are unable to obtain commercial finance at reasonable market interest rates. Household Support, up to a maximum which is equal to the Unemployment Benefit, is made available over 12 months to those who are considering leaving farming. Such assistance may be extended for up to a further 2 years if the applicant takes positive steps to leave farming. Under the Rehabilitation provisions assistance of up to $9,480 (based on $8,000 at 1 July 1985 and indexed to the CPI) is made available to those who have left farming. Part C assistance is initially made in the form of loans, but these are invariably changed to grants and there is no limit on the amount which may be funded in any one year.
